Knlgmngr.CYC-{1984-1995-2023} (link)

Knlgmngr.KL-ONE-{1982}

description::
× generic: frame-language--manager,

"overview of KL-ONE:
KL-ONE is a knowledge representation system in the tradition of semantic networks and frames. It is a frame language that provides a structured inheritance network for representing conceptual information.
*
* **Concepts** in KL-ONE are the basic building blocks of knowledge representation. Concepts can be primitive, meaning that they are not further defined, or defined, meaning that they are defined in terms of other concepts.
*
* **Roles** are relationships between concepts. For example, the concept "Person" might have a role called "has-parent", which would relate a person to their parent.
*
* **Descriptions** in KL-ONE are used to represent the properties and relationships of concepts. A description can be simple, such as "Person has-parent Person", or it can be complex, such as "Person who is a parent of two or more children."
*
* **Inheritance** in KL-ONE is used to organize concepts into a hierarchy. For example, the concept "Person" might inherit from the concept "Animal". This means that everything that is true of an animal is also true of a person.
*
* **KL-ONE also supports multiple inheritance**, which means that a concept can inherit from multiple other concepts. This allows for more complex and nuanced representations of knowledge.
*
* **KL-ONE has a number of features that make it a powerful knowledge representation system:**
* * **Structured inheritance network:** KL-ONE's structured inheritance network allows for efficient reasoning about knowledge.
* * **Complex descriptions:** KL-ONE's complex descriptions allow for the representation of a wide range of knowledge, from simple facts to complex relationships.
* * **Multiple inheritance:** KL-ONE's multiple inheritance allows for more flexible and expressive knowledge representation.
* * **Deductive classifier:** KL-ONE includes a deductive classifier that can be used to validate knowledge bases and deduce new knowledge.
*
* KL-ONE has been used in a variety of applications, including natural language processing, knowledge engineering, and machine learning.
*
* Here is an example of a KL-ONE description:
* ```
* (Concept Person)
* (Subsumes Person Animal)
* (Role has-parent)
* (Description Person who has-parent Person)
* ```
*
* This description says that the concept "Person" subsumes the concept "Animal" and that persons have parents. It also says that a person is defined as someone who has a parent who is also a person.
*
* KL-ONE is a powerful knowledge representation system that can be used to represent a wide range of knowledge. It is a good choice for applications where complex and flexible knowledge representation is needed."
[{2023-10-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/1ad6ed38e0932b22]

name::
* McsEngl.KL-ONE-Knlgmngr!⇒klmrKlone,
* McsEngl.klmrKlone!=KL-ONE--knowledge-manager,
* McsEngl.Knlgmngr.021-KL-ONE!⇒klmrKlone,
* McsEngl.Knlgmngr.KL-ONE!⇒klmrKlone,

evoluting of klmrKlone

description::
"evolution of KL-ONE:
KL-ONE was originally developed in the late 1970s by Ronald J. Brachman and others at Bolt, Beranek and Newman. It was one of the first knowledge representation systems to use a structured inheritance network and complex descriptions.

KL-ONE has evolved over time, with new features being added and existing features being improved. Some of the major milestones in the evolution of KL-ONE include:
* **1980:** KL-ONE is first described in a paper by Brachman.
* **1981:** The first KL-ONE workshop is held.
* **1982:** The first KL-ONE implementation is released.
* **1983:** Brachman and James G. Schmolze publish a paper that describes the semantics and classification of KL-ONE.
* **1985:** The KL-ONE system is used to build the CYC knowledge base.
* **1987:** The KL-ONE family of knowledge representation languages is standardized by the IEEE.
* **1990s:** KL-ONE is used to build a number of other knowledge bases, including the WordNet lexical database and the UMLS Metathesaurus.
* **2000s:** KL-ONE continues to be used in a variety of research and development projects.

Some of the key features that have been added to KL-ONE over time include:
* **Support for multiple inheritance**
* **A deductive classifier**
* **The ability to represent temporal and spatial knowledge**
* **The ability to represent uncertainty**

KL-ONE has also been extended to support new applications, such as natural language processing, machine learning, and web semantics.

Today, KL-ONE is no longer a single system. Instead, it is a family of knowledge representation languages that are based on the original KL-ONE system. Some of the most well-known KL-ONE languages include:
* **Description Logics (DL)**
* **Web Ontology Language (OWL)**
* **Resource Description Framework (RDF)**

These languages are used to build a wide variety of knowledge bases, including the Semantic Web, the Global Biodiversity Information Facility, and the Gene Ontology.

KL-ONE has had a major impact on the field of knowledge representation. It has been used to build a wide variety of knowledge bases and has inspired the development of many new knowledge representation languages. KL-ONE continues to be an important tool for researchers and developers who need to build knowledge-based systems.
[{2023-10-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/1ad6ed38e0932b22]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-klmrKlone,
* McsEngl.klmrKlone'evoluting,

Knlgmngr.MYCIN-{1974..1990s}

description::
"overview of MYCIN:
MYCIN was an early expert system developed in the 1970s at Stanford University. It was designed to help physicians diagnose and treat bacterial infections. MYCIN was a backward chaining expert system, meaning that it started with a hypothesis and then asked questions to confirm or disconfirm that hypothesis.

MYCIN's knowledge base consisted of over 500 production rules. Each production rule represented a piece of knowledge about bacterial infections, such as "If the patient has a fever and a headache, then they may have meningitis." MYCIN would use its knowledge base to ask the physician a series of questions about the patient's symptoms and medical history. Based on the physician's answers, MYCIN would generate a list of possible diagnoses.

MYCIN would then recommend a course of treatment for each diagnosis. The treatment recommendations were based on MYCIN's knowledge of the bacteria that cause each infection, the antibiotics that are effective against those bacteria, and the patient's individual characteristics, such as their age and weight.

MYCIN was evaluated in a number of clinical trials, and it was found to be as accurate as human experts in diagnosing bacterial infections. MYCIN was also found to be more consistent in its treatment recommendations than human experts.

MYCIN was never widely deployed in clinical practice, but it was a landmark achievement in the field of artificial intelligence. MYCIN is considered to be the "granddaddy of all expert systems."

Here are some of the key features of MYCIN:
* **Backward chaining:** MYCIN used backward chaining to reason from a hypothesis to a conclusion.
* **Production rules:** MYCIN's knowledge base was represented as a set of production rules.
* **Expert knowledge:** MYCIN's knowledge base was developed by consulting with experts in the field of infectious disease.
* **Consistency:** MYCIN was more consistent in its treatment recommendations than human experts.

MYCIN was a pioneering expert system that helped to lay the foundation for the field of knowledge-based systems. MYCIN's legacy can be seen in the many expert systems that are used today in a variety of domains, such as medical diagnosis, financial planning, and fraud detection."
[{2023-10-27 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/2afefc8b86a6d9bd]

name::
* McsEngl.Knlgmngr.002-MYCIN,
* McsEngl.Knlgmngr.MYCIN,
* McsEngl.MYCIN-Knlgmngr,
* McsEngl.klmrMycin!=MYCIN--knowledge-manager,

evoluting of klmrMycin

description::
"evolution of MYCIN:
MYCIN was one of the first expert systems to be developed, and it had a significant impact on the evolution of artificial intelligence. It was developed at Stanford University in the early 1970s by Edward Shortliffe and Bruce Buchanan, with the goal of developing a computer system that could assist physicians in the diagnosis and treatment of infectious diseases.

MYCIN was a rule-based system, meaning that it used a set of rules to infer conclusions from data. The rules were developed in collaboration with infectious disease experts, and they encoded their knowledge about the diagnosis and treatment of infections.

MYCIN was able to achieve impressive results in early studies. For example, in one study, MYCIN was able to provide therapy recommendations that were comparable to those of human experts in over 70% of cases.

However, MYCIN also had some limitations. One limitation was that it was very domain-specific, meaning that it could only be used to diagnose and treat a limited range of infections. Another limitation was that the knowledge base was difficult to maintain and update.

Despite its limitations, MYCIN was a groundbreaking achievement in artificial intelligence. It demonstrated that it was possible to develop computer systems that could encode and apply human expertise in complex domains.

MYCIN's development also led to the development of expert system shells, which are software tools that can be used to develop expert systems for a variety of domains. Expert system shells have been used to develop expert systems for a wide range of applications, including medical diagnosis, financial planning, and engineering design.

MYCIN is no longer in use today, but it had a significant impact on the evolution of artificial intelligence. It pioneered the development of rule-based expert systems and expert system shells, which are still used today to develop intelligent systems for a variety of applications.

Here is a brief timeline of the evolution of MYCIN:
* 1972: Work on MYCIN begins at Stanford University.
* 1974: MYCIN is first able to provide therapy recommendations for meningitis cases.
* 1976: MYCIN is tested in a clinical setting at Stanford Medical School.
* 1980: E-MYCIN, an expert system shell based on MYCIN, is released.
* 1984: The book *Rule-Based Expert Systems: The MYCIN Experiments of the Stanford Heuristic Programming Project* is published.
* 1990s: MYCIN is no longer actively developed or used.

MYCIN's evolution reflects the broader evolution of artificial intelligence. Early AI systems, such as MYCIN, were rule-based and domain-specific. Later AI systems, such as machine learning systems, are able to learn from data and generalize to new domains.

Today, AI systems are being used for a wide range of applications, including medical diagnosis, financial planning, and self-driving cars. MYCIN was a pioneer in this field, and it continues to inspire AI researchers today."
[{2023-10-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/d987193f5687a98a]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-klmrMycin,
* McsEngl.klmrMycin'evoluting,

Knlgmngr.CODE4

description::
"CODE4 (Conceptually Oriented Description Environment) is a general purpose knowledge management system intended for analysing, debugging, and delivering knowledge about some domain. It is designed to be easily adaptable to many applications, such as natural language processing, software specification and design, expert systems, general terminological analysis, or teaching subjects such as biology or Unix. It can be learned by non-computer people in a few days."
[{2023-10-27 retrieved} https://www.site.uottawa.ca/kaml/CODE4.html]

"CODE4 knowledge-management-system:
CODE4 is a general-purpose knowledge management system (KMS) that can be used to store, retrieve, and analyze conceptual knowledge. It is intended to be easy to use and flexible enough to meet the needs of a variety of users.

CODE4 has a number of features that make it a powerful KMS:
* **Conceptual modeling:** CODE4 allows users to model their knowledge in a way that is both expressive and easy to understand. This makes it possible to store and retrieve knowledge in a way that is relevant to the user's needs.
* **Automatic inferencing:** CODE4 can automatically infer new knowledge from the knowledge that is stored in the system. This allows users to gain new insights from their knowledge without having to explicitly encode them.
* **Collaboration:** CODE4 supports collaboration between users on knowledge management tasks. This makes it possible to share knowledge and expertise more effectively.
* **Extensibility:** CODE4 is extensible, so users can add new features and functionality to the system to meet their specific needs.

CODE4 has been used in a variety of applications, including:
* **Product design:** CODE4 can be used to store and retrieve knowledge about products, such as their specifications, design constraints, and usage scenarios. This information can be used to improve the design of new products and to troubleshoot problems with existing products.
* **Software development:** CODE4 can be used to store and retrieve knowledge about software, such as its design, implementation, and testing. This information can be used to improve the development process and to ensure the quality of software products.
* **Customer service:** CODE4 can be used to store and retrieve knowledge about customers, such as their preferences, past interactions with the company, and unresolved issues. This information can be used to provide better customer service and to resolve customer problems more quickly.

Overall, CODE4 is a powerful and versatile KMS that can be used to improve knowledge management in a variety of organizations."
[{2023-10-27 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/a911ade8e47b3291]

name::
* McsEngl.CODE4-Knlgmngr,

descriptionLong::
"overview of CODE4 KMS:
CODE4 KMS is a cloud-based knowledge management system developed by the Google AI team. It is a powerful tool that helps organizations to collect, organize, and share knowledge. CODE4 KMS is easy to use and navigate, and it includes a number of features to help users to find the knowledge they need quickly and easily.

Here are some of the key features of CODE4 KMS:
* **Natural language processing (NLP):** CODE4 KMS supports NLP, which allows users to search for knowledge using natural language queries. For example, a user could type in the query "What is the best way to treat a migraine?" and CODE4 KMS would return relevant knowledge articles, documentation, and other resources.
* **Machine learning (ML):** CODE4 KMS also supports ML, which allows users to train the system to identify and extract knowledge from unstructured data sources. This can be useful for extracting knowledge from emails, chat logs, and other types of unstructured data.
* **Knowledge graph:** CODE4 KMS includes a knowledge graph, which is a network of interconnected nodes that represent knowledge entities. The knowledge graph can be used to browse and explore knowledge in a more visual way.
* **Collaboration features:** CODE4 KMS includes collaboration features that allow users to share knowledge with each other, annotate knowledge articles, and create discussion forums.
* **Security and compliance:** CODE4 KMS includes security and compliance features that help organizations to protect their knowledge and ensure compliance with relevant regulations.

CODE4 KMS is a valuable tool for a wide range of organizations, including:
* **Businesses:** CODE4 KMS can be used by businesses to improve their knowledge management practices, share knowledge with employees and customers, and improve decision-making.
* **Educational institutions:** CODE4 KMS can be used by educational institutions to collect and organize knowledge for students and faculty, and to improve the teaching and learning process.
* **Government agencies:** CODE4 KMS can be used by government agencies to collect and organize knowledge about laws, regulations, and policies, and to improve the delivery of government services.
* **Nonprofit organizations:** CODE4 KMS can be used by nonprofit organizations to collect and organize knowledge about their programs and services, and to share knowledge with their stakeholders.

Overall, CODE4 KMS is a powerful and versatile knowledge management system that can be used by organizations of all sizes to improve their knowledge management practices and share knowledge with their employees, customers, and other stakeholders."
[{2023-10-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/4122071e73b35c2]

Knlgmngr.IKARUS

description::
"overview of Intelligent knowledge acquisition and retrieval universal system:
**Intelligent Knowledge Acquisition and Retrieval Universal System (IKARUS)** is a knowledge management system that aims to provide a comprehensive and integrated solution for knowledge acquisition, representation, storage, retrieval, and sharing. It is designed to be a universal system that can be used in a wide variety of domains, including business, education, healthcare, and government.

IKARUS is based on a number of key principles, including:
* **Semantic knowledge representation:** IKARUS uses a semantic knowledge representation model that allows it to represent the meaning of knowledge in a way that is both machine-readable and human-understandable. This makes it possible for IKARUS to reason about knowledge and to generate new knowledge based on existing knowledge.
* **Intelligent knowledge acquisition:** IKARUS provides a number of intelligent knowledge acquisition tools that can be used to extract knowledge from a variety of sources, including unstructured text, databases, and expert systems. This makes it possible to create and maintain large knowledge bases without the need for manual data entry.
* **Machine learning:** IKARUS uses machine learning techniques to learn from user interactions and to improve its performance over time. This makes IKARUS more intelligent and adaptive, and allows it to better meet the needs of its users.

IKARUS provides a number of features that make it a powerful and versatile knowledge management system, including:
* **Knowledge search and retrieval:** IKARUS provides a powerful knowledge search and retrieval engine that allows users to find the information they need quickly and easily. Users can search for knowledge using a variety of criteria, including keywords, semantic concepts, and relationships between concepts.
* **Knowledge reasoning and inference:** IKARUS can reason about knowledge and generate new knowledge based on existing knowledge. This makes it possible for IKARUS to answer complex questions that would be difficult or impossible to answer using traditional search engines.
* **Knowledge sharing and collaboration:** IKARUS allows users to share knowledge and collaborate with each other. Users can create and share knowledge bases, and they can work together to solve problems and make decisions.

IKARUS is a powerful and versatile knowledge management system that can be used in a wide variety of domains. It is still under development, but it has the potential to revolutionize the way that we acquire, manage, and use knowledge.

Here are some potential applications of IKARUS:
* **Business:** IKARUS can be used to manage customer knowledge, product knowledge, and market knowledge. It can also be used to develop expert systems and decision support systems.
* **Education:** IKARUS can be used to create and manage knowledge bases for educational resources, such as textbooks, articles, and videos. It can also be used to develop intelligent tutoring systems and adaptive learning systems.
* **Healthcare:** IKARUS can be used to manage patient knowledge, medical knowledge, and drug knowledge. It can also be used to develop expert systems for medical diagnosis and treatment planning.
* **Government:** IKARUS can be used to manage citizen knowledge, policy knowledge, and law knowledge. It can also be used to develop expert systems for public policy analysis and decision making.

IKARUS is a powerful tool that has the potential to revolutionize the way that we acquire, manage, and use knowledge. It is still under development, but it has the potential to have a significant impact on a wide range of industries and sectors."
[{2023-10-28 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/eae955702a49c781]

descriptionLong::
"evolution of IKARUS-KRS:
IKARUS-KRS is an AI system developed by the German Aerospace Center (DLR). It is a knowledge-based reasoning system that is designed to solve complex problems in the areas of aerospace, robotics, and artificial intelligence.

**IKARUS-KRS's early years**
IKARUS-KRS was first introduced in the early 2000s. It was developed in response to the need for an AI system that could reason about complex systems and make decisions in real time.
IKARUS-KRS is based on a number of different AI technologies, including:
* Knowledge representation: IKARUS-KRS uses a knowledge representation language called KIF to store its knowledge. KIF is a powerful language that allows IKARUS-KRS to represent a wide range of different types of knowledge, including facts, rules, and relationships.
* Reasoning: IKARUS-KRS uses a variety of reasoning algorithms to solve problems. These algorithms include forward chaining, backward chaining, and abduction.
* Planning: IKARUS-KRS can also be used to plan and execute actions. It does this by using a planning algorithm called A*.

**IKARUS-KRS's evolution**
Since its introduction, IKARUS-KRS has evolved to become a more powerful and versatile AI system. Some of the key improvements that have been made to IKARUS-KRS include:
* The addition of new knowledge representation languages: In addition to KIF, IKARUS-KRS now also supports other knowledge representation languages, such as OWL and SWRL. This makes it easier to integrate IKARUS-KRS with other AI systems.
* The development of new reasoning algorithms: IKARUS-KRS now includes a number of new reasoning algorithms, such as non-monotonic reasoning and probabilistic reasoning. These algorithms allow IKRUS-KRS to reason about more complex problems.
* The improvement of planning capabilities: IKARUS-KRS's planning capabilities have also been improved. It can now plan for more complex tasks and it can also take into account uncertainty in the environment.

**IKARUS-KRS today**
Today, IKARUS-KRS is used in a variety of different applications, including:
* Aerospace: IKARUS-KRS is used to support the development of new aerospace systems, such as aircraft and spacecraft. It is also used to monitor and control aerospace systems during operation.
* Robotics: IKARUS-KRS is used to develop and control robots. It is also used to plan and execute robot missions.
* Artificial intelligence: IKARUS-KRS is used to develop new AI algorithms and systems. It is also used to evaluate the performance of AI systems.

**IKARUS-KRS's future**
DLR is continuing to invest in the development of IKARUS-KRS. Some of the areas that DLR is focusing on include:
* The development of new knowledge representation languages: DLR is working on developing new knowledge representation languages that are better suited for representing the knowledge that is needed to solve real-world problems.
* The development of new reasoning algorithms: DLR is also working on developing new reasoning algorithms that are more efficient and effective.
* The improvement of planning capabilities: DLR is working on improving IKARUS-KRS's planning capabilities so that it can plan for more complex tasks and take into account more uncertainty in the environment.

As AI continues to evolve, IKARUS-KRS is poised to play an increasingly important role in the development and deployment of new AI systems."
[{2023-10-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/def7b1a45dc3d641]
===
"evolution of IKARUS-KMS:
IKARUS-KMS is a knowledge management system (KMS) developed by the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich (ETH Zurich). It was originally released in 1999 and has since evolved to become one of the most powerful and versatile KMSs available.

**IKARUS-KMS in the early years**
The early versions of IKARUS-KMS focused on providing a central repository for storing and managing knowledge. It could be used to store a variety of different types of content, including documents, images, videos, and web pages. IKARUS-KMS also provided a number of features for organizing and searching knowledge, such as tagging, versioning, and full-text search.

**The evolution of IKARUS-KMS**
Over the years, IKARUS-KMS has evolved to become a more sophisticated and feature-rich KMS. Some of the key enhancements that have been made include:
* Support for collaborative knowledge management: IKARUS-KMS now supports a variety of features for collaborative knowledge management, such as discussion forums, wikis, and blogs. This allows users to work together to create, share, and manage knowledge.
* Integration with other systems: IKARUS-KMS can now be integrated with a variety of other systems, such as content management systems (CMSs), enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems, and customer relationship management (CRM) systems. This allows users to manage their knowledge in a single place and to access it from anywhere.
* Support for new content types: IKARUS-KMS now supports a wider range of content types, including social media posts, emails, and chat transcripts. This allows users to capture and manage all of their knowledge in one place.

**IKARUS-KMS today**
Today, IKARUS-KMS is used by a wide range of organizations, including universities, research institutes, government agencies, and businesses. It is a popular choice for organizations that need a powerful and versatile KMS to manage their knowledge assets.

**The future of IKARUS-KMS**
The developers of IKARUS-KMS are continuing to invest in the platform and to develop new features. Some of the areas that they are focusing on include:
* Support for artificial intelligence (AI): IKARUS-KMS is being integrated with AI technologies to make it more intelligent and user-friendly. For example, IKARUS-KMS can now use AI to recommend relevant content to users and to automate tasks such as knowledge extraction and classification.
* Support for the Semantic Web: IKARUS-KMS is being integrated with the Semantic Web to make it easier to share and link knowledge across different systems and organizations.
* Support for new devices and platforms: IKARUS-KMS is being developed to support a wider range of devices and platforms, including mobile devices and wearable devices.

As knowledge management becomes increasingly important for organizations, IKARUS-KMS is well-positioned to remain a leading KMS platform."
[{2023-10-30 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/def7b1a45dc3d641]

relation-to-programing-language of lagKnlg

description::
"knowledge-representation-language vs programming-language:
Knowledge representation languages (KRLs) and programming languages serve different purposes and have distinct characteristics. Here's a comparison between the two:

1. Purpose:
- Knowledge Representation Language (KRL): KRLs are designed to represent and manipulate knowledge or information in a form that is understandable to both humans and machines. They are used in artificial intelligence (AI) and knowledge-based systems to model, store, and reason about information.
- Programming Language: Programming languages are used to write instructions and algorithms that tell a computer how to perform specific tasks. They are used for developing software, applications, and systems.

2. Abstraction:
- KRLs typically abstract away from low-level implementation details and focus on expressing concepts, facts, and relationships.
- Programming languages often deal with low-level details and are used to specify step-by-step procedures for solving problems.

3. Syntax and Semantics:
- KRLs often have a more natural language-like syntax and semantics to facilitate easy understanding by domain experts.
- Programming languages have syntax and semantics that are designed for precise and unambiguous execution by a computer.

4. Human Readability:
- KRLs aim for human readability and comprehension, as they are often used for knowledge sharing, expert systems, and knowledge representation.
- Programming languages are primarily meant for machine execution, and their syntax may be more complex and less human-friendly.

5. Inference and Reasoning:
- KRLs are designed to support various forms of reasoning and inference, such as deduction, induction, and abduction, which are essential in AI and expert systems.
- Programming languages do not inherently provide reasoning capabilities and are focused on algorithm execution.

6. Examples:
- Examples of KRLs include RDF (Resource Description Framework), OWL (Web Ontology Language), and Prolog (a logic programming language often used for knowledge representation).
- Examples of programming languages include Python, Java, C++, and JavaScript.

7. Use Cases:
- KRLs are used in applications like semantic web, expert systems, natural language processing, and knowledge-based systems.
- Programming languages are used for developing a wide range of software applications, including web development, mobile apps, desktop applications, and system software.

In summary, KRLs and programming languages are distinct in their purposes and design. KRLs are primarily used for representing and manipulating knowledge in a human-readable format, while programming languages are used to instruct computers to perform specific tasks. While there may be some overlap and integration in certain applications (such as using KRLs to define knowledge bases for AI systems), they remain fundamentally different in their roles and functionalities."
[{2023-10-23 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/7b4ed7ec-2f8e-4d0b-888c-7ee3aed90417]

name::
* McsEngl.lagCpgm'relation-to-knowledge-language,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg'relation-to-programing-language,

descriptionLong::
"knowledge-representation-language vs programming-language:
**Knowledge representation languages (KRLs)** are formal languages used to represent knowledge in a way that can be understood and processed by computers. KRLs are used in a variety of artificial intelligence applications, such as expert systems, natural language processing, and robotics.

**Programming languages**, on the other hand, are used to write programs that perform specific tasks. Programming languages are more general-purpose than KRLs, and can be used to develop a wide range of applications, from web browsers to video games.

**Key differences between KRLs and programming languages:**
* **Purpose:** KRLs are designed specifically to represent knowledge, while programming languages are designed to write programs.
* **Expressiveness:** KRLs are typically more expressive than programming languages, meaning that they can represent a wider range of knowledge concepts.
* **Ease of use:** Programming languages are generally easier to use than KRLs, as they are designed to be programmed by humans.
* **Performance:** KRLs can be slower than programming languages, as they need to perform additional reasoning tasks.

**Examples of KRLs:**
* OWL (Web Ontology Language)
* RDF (Resource Description Framework)
* Prolog
* Description logics
* Frames

**Examples of programming languages:**
* Python
* Java
* C/C++
* JavaScript
* Go

**Which one to use?**
The choice of whether to use a KRL or a programming language depends on the specific application. If the goal is to represent a large amount of knowledge and perform complex reasoning tasks, then a KRL is a good choice. If the goal is to develop a specific application, such as a web browser or a video game, then a programming language is a better choice.

Here are some specific examples of when to use a KRL or a programming language:
* **Use a KRL:**
* To develop an expert system that can diagnose diseases or recommend products.
* To build a natural language processing system that can understand and generate human language.
* To develop a robotic system that can plan and execute actions in the real world.
* **Use a programming language:**
* To develop a web browser that displays web pages.
* To build a video game that allows users to interact with a virtual world.
* To develop a mobile app that helps users manage their tasks.

In some cases, it may be beneficial to use a combination of a KRL and a programming language. For example, a KRL can be used to represent the knowledge of an expert system, and a programming language can be used to implement the reasoning engine.

Ultimately, the best way to choose between a KRL and a programming language is to consider the specific requirements of the application."
[{2023-10-23 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/1217e0651f4ac5a6]

evoluting of techKnlg

description::
"evolution of knowledge-representation-languages:
The evolution of knowledge representation languages (KRLs) can be divided into four broad phases:

**Phase 1: Early KRLs (1960s-1970s)**
Early KRLs were focused on representing simple facts and relationships. They were often based on Lisp or Prolog, and they used a variety of different representations, such as logical expressions, frames, and rules.
Some examples of early KRLs include:
* **SHRDLU** (1970): A language for representing and reasoning about the physical world.
* **ELIZA** (1966): A language for representing and reasoning about human natural language.
* **MYCIN** (1972): A language for representing and reasoning about medical knowledge.

**Phase 2: Ontologies and Description Logics (1980s-1990s)**
In the 1980s and 1990s, there was a growing interest in using KRLs to represent ontologies, which are formal representations of knowledge about a particular domain. This led to the development of new KRLs based on description logics, which are a family of formal logics that are well-suited for representing ontologies.
Some examples of KRLs from this phase include:
* **LOOM** (1987): One of the first ontological KRLs.
* **KL-ONE** (1985): Another early ontological KRL.
* **SHOE** (1994): A KRL based on description logics that was designed for representing ontologies in a variety of domains.

**Phase 3: The Web Ontology Language (OWL) (2000s)**
In the 2000s, the Web Ontology Language (OWL) was developed as a standard KRL for representing ontologies on the Web. OWL is based on description logics, and it provides a rich set of features for representing different types of knowledge, such as classes, individuals, properties, and relationships.
OWL is now the most widely used KRL for representing ontologies in a variety of domains, including bioinformatics, medicine, and engineering.

**Phase 4: Modern KRLs (2010s-present)**
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in developing new KRLs that are more expressive and powerful than OWL. Some of these new KRLs are based on new formal logics, such as modal logics and temporal logics. Others are based on new machine learning techniques, such as deep learning.
Some examples of modern KRLs include:
* **SWRL** (2004): A KRL that combines OWL with rules.
* **SPIN** (2011): A KRL that allows users to add new semantics to OWL ontologies.
* **RDFS++** (2012): A KRL that extends OWL with new features for representing temporal and spatial knowledge.
* **WebReason** (2016): A KRL that is based on modal logic and allows users to reason about counterfactuals and possible worlds.

The evolution of KRLs has been driven by a number of factors, including the need to represent more complex knowledge, the need to reason about knowledge in more sophisticated ways, and the need to integrate knowledge from different sources.

Modern KRLs are still under development, but they have the potential to revolutionize the way we represent and reason about knowledge in AI systems."
[{2023-10-23 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/3c669bacca1bb3be]

"evolution of knowledge-representation-languages:
The evolution of knowledge representation languages is a fascinating journey that has played a significant role in the development of artificial intelligence and related fields. These languages are designed to capture and model knowledge in a way that can be used by computers for reasoning and problem-solving. Here is an overview of the key milestones and stages in the evolution of knowledge representation languages:

1. Early Symbolic Notation (1950s-1960s):
- In the early days of AI research, knowledge representation involved symbolic notations. Researchers used formal logic, such as first-order logic and propositional logic, to represent knowledge.
- Researchers also utilized early programming languages to represent knowledge, which were often ad hoc and lacked formal semantics.

2. Frame-Based Systems (late 1960s-1970s):
- Frame-based knowledge representation systems, such as Minsky's "frames," introduced the idea of organizing knowledge in structured entities called frames. These frames contained slots and fillers for organizing and storing information.

3. Semantic Networks (1960s-1980s):
- Semantic networks represented knowledge using nodes and links to connect concepts and their relationships. This approach made it easier to model hierarchical and associative relationships between concepts.

4. Rule-Based Systems (1970s-1980s):
- Rule-based systems used production rules to represent knowledge in the form of "if-then" statements. These systems were particularly useful for expert systems and rule-based reasoning.

5. Description Logics (1980s-present):
- Description logics are a family of formal knowledge representation languages that are based on first-order logic and set theory. They underpin modern ontology languages and are used in the Semantic Web and ontology modeling.

6. Ontology Languages (late 1990s-present):
- Ontologies, represented using languages like OWL (Web Ontology Language), RDF (Resource Description Framework), and RDFS (Resource Description Framework Schema), have gained prominence for representing knowledge in a structured, machine-readable format. These ontologies are used for semantic web applications and knowledge organization.

7. CycL (1984-present):
- CycL is a knowledge representation language associated with the Cyc project, which aims to capture common-sense knowledge in a machine-readable format. It employs a rich, formalized language for representing a wide range of knowledge.

8. RDF and Linked Data (2000s-present):
- RDF and linked data principles have become fundamental for representing and connecting knowledge on the web. They allow for the creation of knowledge graphs and the integration of data from diverse sources.

9. Neural Networks and Embeddings (2010s-present):
- In recent years, deep learning techniques, particularly neural network-based embeddings, have played a significant role in learning and representing knowledge from large datasets. Embeddings like Word2Vec, GloVe, and BERT capture semantic relationships between words and concepts.

The evolution of knowledge representation languages reflects the ongoing quest to make computers understand and manipulate human knowledge more effectively. Modern knowledge representation often involves a combination of these approaches, and research continues to explore ways to make knowledge representation more efficient and adaptable for various AI applications."
[{2023-10-23 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/d4587416-de37-4dd4-8641-a1bdd7b9a0ab]

{2021..2030} of techKnlg

description::
* {2020s}: AI is used to develop new products and services, such as self-driving cars and virtual assistants.
* {2023}:
- Douglas-Lenat, creator of Cyc, died. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Lenat]
- GPT-4 announcement on 2023-03-14.
* {2022} ChatGPT was released in November 2022 and quickly gained popularity due to its ability to engage in open-ended, fluent conversations. It could generate human-quality text, translate languages, write different kinds of creative content, and answer your questions in an informative way. [https://bard.google.com/]
* {2021} RDF-star: is an extension of RDF that allows triples to be nested within other triples.

name::
* McsEngl.techKnlg'{2030i10},
* McsEngl.{techInfo'2030i10}-techKnlg,

{2011..2020} of techKnlg

description::
* {2010s}: AI is widely adopted in a variety of industries.
* {2020}: OWL 2 WSDL Profile is introduced, enabling the integration of OWL ontologies into Web Services Description Language (WSDL).
* {2018-2019} Transfer Learning: particularly using pre-trained models like BERT for natural language understanding, became a prominent strategy for various NLP tasks. It significantly reduced the need for massive labeled datasets. [https://chat.openai.com/]
* {2017}:
- the Transformer architecture was introduced in large-language-models.
- SHACL Shapes Constraint Language: is a W3C Recommendation that provides a way to describe and validate the structure and constraints of RDF graphs.
* {2016} WebReason: A KRL that is based on modal logic and allows users to reason about counterfactuals and possible worlds.
* {2015} Deep Reinforcement Learning: The combination of deep learning with reinforcement learning led to significant progress in AI, with algorithms like AlphaGo beating world champions in board games. [https://chat.openai.com/]
* {2014} JSON-LD: JSON Linked Data is a JSON-based serialization for RDF data.
* {2012} RDFS++: A KRL that extends OWL with new features for representing temporal and spatial knowledge.

name::
* McsEngl.techKnlg'{2000i10},
* McsEngl.{techInfo'2000i10}-techKnlg,

{1981..1990} of techKnlg

description::
* {1980s}: Machine learning becomes a popular subfield of AI.
* The expert systems of the early 1980s proved to be difficult to bulid because of the challenge of capturing all of an expert's knowledge. They were also difficult to maintain, because their large rule bases had little organization. Most expert systems were stand-alone applications on dedicated workstations. [BYTE, JUL 1993, 107]
* {1987} LOOM: One of the first ontological KRLs.
* {1985} KL-ONE: Another early ontological KRL.
* {1984} Cyc: Lenat initiates the Cyc project at MCC.
* {1982} Doug Lenat: Publishes the Knowledge Based Systems in Artificial Intelligence (1982, McGraw-Hill)

name::
* McsEngl.techKnlg'{1990i10},
* McsEngl.{techInfo'1990i10}-techKnlg,

description::
* In the 1970s, researchers began to develop knowledge-based systems (KBSs). KBSs are AI systems that use explicit knowledge to solve problems. This knowledge is represented in a variety of ways, such as logic rules, frames, and semantic nets. [https://bard.google.com/]
* Development of knowledge representation systems such as KL-ONE and PROLOG.
* {1972-1976} MYCIN is notable example of early expert systems.

concept-mining of lagLgkl

description::
"overview of concept mining:
**Concept mining** is the process of extracting concepts from unstructured data, such as text, images, and audio. It is a subfield of knowledge discovery in databases (KDD) and text mining, and it uses a variety of techniques from artificial intelligence and statistics to identify and extract meaningful concepts from large datasets.

Concepts are abstract representations of real-world entities and ideas. They can be simple, such as "dog" or "house," or more complex, such as "democracy" or "artificial intelligence." Concepts can also be related to each other in various ways, such as through hypernymy (is-a relationship), meronymy (part-of relationship), or synonymy (similar meaning).

Concept mining is a powerful tool for discovering hidden knowledge in large datasets. It can be used for a variety of tasks, such as:
* **Topic modeling:** Identifying the main topics or themes in a collection of documents
* **Ontology construction:** Building knowledge bases that represent the relationships between concepts
* **Information retrieval:** Improving the accuracy and efficiency of search engines
* **Natural language processing:** Developing systems that can understand and generate human language
* **Machine learning:** Improving the performance of machine learning algorithms by providing them with better representations of the data

Concept mining is used in a wide range of industries, including healthcare, finance, marketing, and education. For example, concept mining can be used to identify the most common diseases and treatments in a medical database, or to discover the most popular products and brands in a social media dataset.

Here is a high-level overview of the concept mining process:
1. **Preprocessing:** The data is cleaned and prepared for analysis. This may involve removing noise, correcting errors, and stemming and lemmatizing words.
2. **Feature extraction:** Features are extracted from the data that are relevant to the concept mining task. For example, in text mining, features may include words, phrases, and syntactic patterns.
3. **Concept representation:** The features are used to represent the concepts in a way that is suitable for the concept mining algorithm. This may involve creating vectors of features or using a graph-based representation.
4. **Concept mining:** A concept mining algorithm is applied to the data to extract the concepts. There are a variety of different concept mining algorithms available, each with its own strengths and weaknesses.
5. **Concept evaluation:** The extracted concepts are evaluated to ensure that they are meaningful and accurate. This may involve using human experts to review the concepts or using automated evaluation metrics.

Concept mining is a complex and challenging task, but it has the potential to provide valuable insights into large datasets. As new concept mining algorithms and techniques are developed, it is likely to become an increasingly important tool for a wide range of applications."
[{2023-10-27 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/65aecaa8a9ec5dac]

name::
* McsEngl.concept-mining//lagLgkl,
* McsEngl.lagLgkl'concept-mining,

semantic-parsing of lagLgkl

description::
"Semantic parsing is the task of converting a natural language utterance to a logical form: a machine-understandable representation of its meaning.[1] Semantic parsing can thus be understood as extracting the precise meaning of an utterance. Applications of semantic parsing include machine translation,[2] question answering,[1][3] ontology induction,[4] automated reasoning,[5] and code generation.[6][7] The phrase was first used in the 1970s by Yorick Wilks as the basis for machine translation programs working with only semantic representations.[8]"
[{2023-04-02 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_parsing]

name::
* McsEngl.lagLgkl'semantic-parsing,
* McsEngl.semantic-parsing,

lagLgkl.Abstract-Meaning-Representation

description::
"Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR)[1][2] is a semantic representation language. AMR graphs are rooted, labeled, directed, acyclic graphs (DAGs), comprising whole sentences. They are intended to abstract away from syntactic representations, in the sense that sentences which are similar in meaning should be assigned the same AMR, even if they are not identically worded. By nature, the AMR language is biased towards English – it is not meant to function as an international auxiliary language.
Abstract Meaning Representations have originally been introduced by Langkilde and Knight (1998)[3] as a derivation from the Penman Sentence Plan Language,[4] they are thus continuing a long tradition in Natural Language Generation and this has been their original domain of application. AMRs have re-gained attention since Banarescu et al. (2013),[1] in particular, this includes the extension to novel tasks such as machine translation and natural language understanding. The modern (post-2010) AMR format preserves the syntax and many syntactic conceptions of the original AMR format but has been thoroughly revised to better align with PropBank. Moreover, AMR has been extended with formal conventions for metadata and conventions for entity linking (here, linking with Wikipedia entries).
Existing AMR technology includes tools and libraries for parsing,[5] visualization,[6] and surface generation[7] as well as a considerable number of publicly available data sets. Many of these resources are collected at the AMR homepage[8] at ISI/USC where AMR technology has been originally developed."
[{2023-04-02 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_Meaning_Representation]

name::
* McsEngl.AMR!=Abstract-Meaning-Representation-lagLgkl,
* McsEngl.lagLgkl.Abstract-Meaning-Representation,

lagLgkl.Conceptual-Dependency-Theory

description::
"overview of Conceptual Dependency Theory:
Conceptual Dependency Theory is a knowledge representation framework developed by Roger C. Schank and Robert P. Abelson in the 1970s. This theory aims to model human cognition and understanding of natural language by representing knowledge in the form of conceptual structures called "conceptual dependencies." It is one of the early approaches to knowledge representation in the field of artificial intelligence and cognitive science. Here's an overview of Conceptual Dependency Theory:

1. **Basic Idea:** Conceptual Dependency Theory posits that human understanding and language comprehension can be represented as a set of fundamental, abstract concepts and their relationships. These abstract concepts serve as building blocks for constructing more complex representations of knowledge and understanding.

2. **Conceptual Dependencies:** The central elements of this theory are conceptual dependencies, which are used to represent the meaning of a sentence or a situation. A conceptual dependency consists of several components:
- **Action:** An action is a central concept that describes what is happening or being described in a sentence, such as "eat" or "give."
- **Object:** Objects are entities or things involved in the action, such as "John" or "apple."
- **Attribute:** Attributes provide additional information about an object, such as "red" for "apple."
- **Modifiers:** Modifiers are used to specify conditions or circumstances related to the action or object, such as "quickly" for "eat."
- **Time:** Time elements provide information about when the action occurs, like "yesterday" or "now."

3. **Conceptual Dependency Grammar:** Conceptual Dependency Theory uses a specialized grammar to represent sentences in terms of these conceptual dependencies. This grammar allows for the transformation of natural language sentences into a structured, abstract representation that captures the underlying meaning.

4. **Inference and Reasoning:** The theory includes mechanisms for performing inference and reasoning. It allows for the recognition of relationships, the generation of implications, and the understanding of context.

5. **Limitations:** Conceptual Dependency Theory, while innovative, has some limitations. It can be challenging to represent certain nuances of meaning and complex relationships, and it doesn't always scale well to more extensive knowledge domains. As a result, other knowledge representation models and approaches have gained prominence in artificial intelligence, such as frame-based systems and ontologies.

6. **Influence:** Despite its limitations, Conceptual Dependency Theory had a significant influence on the development of natural language processing and early AI systems. It contributed to the exploration of knowledge representation and understanding in the field.

7. **Evolution:** Over time, Conceptual Dependency Theory has evolved and has been incorporated into various other cognitive and AI models. Elements of it can still be seen in some modern approaches to knowledge representation and natural language understanding.

In summary, Conceptual Dependency Theory is a theory of knowledge representation that seeks to capture the essence of human cognition and language comprehension through abstract conceptual structures. While it is no longer the dominant model for AI knowledge representation, it has played a foundational role in the history of artificial intelligence and cognitive science."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/5596bf85-a830-4ee1-9a2c-5c5a1eb3c481]

name::
* McsEngl.Conceptual-Dependency-Theory,
* McsEngl.lagLgkl.Conceptual-Dependency-Theory,

lagLgkl.embeddings

description::
"overview of embeddings:
Embeddings are a mathematical representation of data in a lower-dimensional space that preserves the underlying relationships between the data points. Embeddings are often used to represent complex data types, such as images, text, or audio, in a way that machine learning algorithms can easily process.

Embeddings are learned from data, and the specific learning algorithm used will depend on the type of data being embedded. For example, word embeddings are learned from text data, while image embeddings are learned from image data.

Once embeddings have been learned, they can be used for a variety of machine learning tasks. For example, word embeddings can be used for tasks such as sentiment analysis, text classification, and machine translation. Image embeddings can be used for tasks such as image classification and object detection.

Here are some of the benefits of using embeddings:
* **Reduced dimensionality:** Embeddings can be used to reduce the dimensionality of data, which can make machine learning algorithms more efficient and less prone to overfitting.
* **Improved performance:** Embeddings have been shown to improve the performance of machine learning algorithms on a variety of tasks.
* **Interpretability:** Embeddings can be used to visualize the relationships between data points, which can help to interpret the results of machine learning models.

Here are some examples of how embeddings are used in practice:
* **Search engines:** Search engines use word embeddings to match search queries to relevant documents.
* **Social media:** Social media platforms use word embeddings to recommend content to users and to identify abusive content.
* **Recommender systems:** Recommender systems use word embeddings to recommend products or services to users based on their past behavior.
* **Machine translation:** Machine translation systems use word embeddings to translate text from one language to another.

Embeddings are a powerful tool that can be used to improve the performance of machine learning algorithms on a variety of tasks. As machine learning continues to develop, embeddings are likely to play an even more important role in the field.
Sources: encord.com/blog/embeddings-machine-learning/"
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/1a0560b1ec4fbe96]

name::
* McsEngl.embeddings,
* McsEngl.lagLgkl.embeddings,

lagKnlg.controlled-natural-language-018

description::
· controlled-natural-language is a-propositional-language that uses a-subset of a-natural-language to make it unambiguous and monosemantic to be-understood by machines.

name::
* McsEngl.CNL!=controlled-natural-language,
* McsEngl.controlled-natural-language!⇒lagCdnl,
* McsEngl.lagCdnl!=ControlleD-Natural-Language,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.003-controlled-natural-language!⇒lagCdnl,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.controlled-natural-language!⇒lagCdnl,
* McsEngl.lagPpsl.controlled-natural-language!⇒lagCdnl,
* McsEngl.machine-oriented-controlled-natural-language!⇒lagCdnl,

descriptionLong::
"This paper presents a survey of research in controlled natural languages that can be used as high-level knowledge representation languages.
Over the past 10 years or so, a number of machine-oriented controlled natural languages have emerged that can be used as high-level interface languages to various kinds of knowledge systems.
These languages are relevant to the area of computational linguistics since they have two very interesting properties: firstly, they look informal like natural languages and are therefore easier to write and understand by humans than formal languages; secondly, they are precisely defined subsets of natural languages and can be translated automatically (and often deterministically) into a formal target language and then be used for automated reasoning.
We present and compare the most mature of these novel languages, show how they can balance the disadvantages of natural languages and formal languages for knowledge representation, and discuss how domain specialists can be supported writing specifications in controlled natural language."
[{2021-01-28} http://web.science.mq.edu.au/~rolfs/papers/coling10-schwitter.pdf]

info-resource of lagCdnl

description::
* Controlled Natural Languages for Knowledge Representation, Rolf Schwitter, Centre for Language Technology, Macquarie University, Rolf.Schwitter@mq.edu.au, http://web.science.mq.edu.au/~rolfs/papers/coling10-schwitter.pdf,

name::
* McsEngl.lagCdnl'Infrsc,

lagCdnl.ACE

description::
"overview of attempto-controlled-English:
Attempto Controlled English (ACE) is a controlled natural language (CNL) that is designed to bridge the gap between natural language and formal languages. It is a restricted form of English that allows for precise, unambiguous representation of information, making it suitable for various applications in fields such as computer science, artificial intelligence, and knowledge representation.

Here's an overview of Attempto Controlled English:
1. **Purpose**: ACE is primarily used for knowledge representation and natural language processing. It provides a way to express complex concepts and formal knowledge using a simplified subset of English, making it accessible to both humans and computers.

2. **Simplicity**: ACE is designed to be easily understandable by people with a basic understanding of English. It uses simplified grammar and vocabulary to reduce ambiguity and enhance precision.

3. **Formality**: Despite its simplicity, ACE retains the formality necessary for machine processing. It enforces strict rules for sentence structure and word usage to ensure clarity.

4. **Ambiguity Reduction**: One of the primary goals of ACE is to eliminate ambiguities that are inherent in standard English. This is achieved through structured sentences and controlled vocabulary.

5. **Applications**: ACE has found applications in various domains, including natural language interfaces for databases, knowledge representation, specification of business rules, and communication with intelligent systems.

6. **Semantics**: ACE is equipped with a formal semantics that enables precise translation into formal logic, which can then be processed by computers for various applications. This formalization is crucial for computational analysis.

7. **ACE Editor**: There is an ACE Editor tool that assists users in writing and validating ACE sentences. It helps ensure that the input conforms to the ACE grammar rules.

8. **Translation**: ACE can be translated into various formal representations, such as first-order logic or semantic web languages like OWL (Web Ontology Language), making it a valuable tool for converting natural language knowledge into machine-understandable formats.

9. **Developed by Attempto Project**: ACE was developed as part of the Attempto Project at the University of Zurich and is continually being developed and refined.

10. **Natural Language Interface**: One of the significant applications of ACE is providing natural language interfaces to databases and knowledge bases. Users can query structured data using English-like sentences.

In summary, Attempto Controlled English (ACE) is a restricted form of English that balances the need for human understandability with machine processability. It has applications in various fields where precise representation of knowledge is essential, such as AI, databases, and knowledge representation systems."
[{2023-10-23 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/d19c460e-33cf-48e4-b88b-6be822f0498c]

name::
* McsEngl.ACE!=attempto-controlled-English!⇒lagAcen,
* McsEngl.attempto-controlled-English!⇒lagAcen,
* McsEngl.lagAcen,
* McsEngl.lagAcen!=Attempto-Controlled-ENglish,
* McsEngl.lagCdnl.Ace!⇒lagAcen,

descriptionLong::
"ACE (Fuchs et al., 2008) is a CNL that covers a well-defined subset of English that can be translated unambiguously into first-order logic via discourse representation structures (Kamp and Reyle, 1993) and then be used for automated reasoning. ACE is defined by a small set of construction rules that describe its syntax and a small set of interpretation rules that disambiguate constructs that might appear ambiguous in full English. The vocabulary of ACE consists of predefined function words (e.g. determiners, conjunctions, and pronouns), some predefined fixed phrases (e.g. there is, it is false that), and content words (nouns, proper names, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs). ACE supports language constructs such as:
• active and passive verbs (and modal verbs);
• strong negation (e.g. no, does not) and weak negation (e.g. is is not provable that);
• subject and object relative clauses;
• declarative, interrogative, imperative and conditional sentences;
• various forms of anaphoric references to noun phrases (e.g. he, himself, the man, X).
It is important to note that the meaning of words in ACE is not predefined; the user is expected to define their meaning by ACE sentences or import these definitions from an existing formal ontology.
Here is a simple example of an ACE text together with a question:
Every company that buys at least three machines gets a discount. Six Swiss companies each buy one machine. A German company buys four machines. Who gets a discount?
Note that ACE uses disambiguation markers (e.g. each) on the surface level and mathematical background knowledge about natural numbers in order to answer the question above. This mathematical knowledge is implemented as a set of Prolog predicates which are executed during the proof (question answering process).
ACE is supported by various tools[2], among them a text editor that helps users to construct correct ACE sentences with the help of hints and error messages, a parser that translates ACE texts into discourse representation structures, a paraphraser that reflects the interpretation of the machine in CNL, and a Satchmo-style reasoning engine that can be used for consistency and redundancy checking as well as for question answering. Applications of ACE include software and hardware specifications, agent control, legal and medical regulations, and ontology construction.
[2] http://attempto.ifi.uzh.ch/site/tools/"
[{2021-01-28} http://web.science.mq.edu.au/~rolfs/papers/coling10-schwitter.pdf]

lexicon of lagAcen

description::
· it is-written in Prolog.
· there are 2: a-common-Clex and a-user-Ulex.
· contains 11 different word classes: adverbs, intransitive adjectives, transitive adjectives, countable nouns, mass nouns, measurement nouns, proper names, intransitive verbs, transitive verbs, ditransitive verbs, and prepositions.
[{2021-01-30} http://attempto.ifi.uzh.ch/site/docs/ace_lexicon.html]
· ~100,000 entries.
[{2021-01-30} https://github.com/Attempto]

name::
* McsEngl.lagAcen'lexicon,

info-resource of lagAcen

description::
* http://attempto.ifi.uzh.ch/site/,
* https://github.com/Attempto,
* http://attempto.ifi.uzh.ch/aceview/,

name::
* McsEngl.lagAcen'Infrsc,

lagCdnl.ClearTalk

description::
"ClearTalk is a controlled natural language—a kind of a formal language for expressing information that is designed to be both human-readable (being based on English) and easily processed by a computer.
Anyone who can read English can immediately read ClearTalk, and the people who write ClearTalk learn to write it while using it. The ClearTalk system itself does most of the training through use: the restrictions are shown by menus and templates and are enforced by immediate syntactic checks. By consistently using ClearTalk for its output, a system reinforces the acceptable syntactic forms.[1]
It is used by the experimental knowledge management software Ikarus and by a knowledge base management system Fact Guru.[2]"
[{2021-01-30} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ClearTalk]

name::
* McsEngl.ClearTalk-lagCdnl,
* McsEngl.lagCdnl.ClearTalk,

evaluation of lagPpsl

description::
· the-inventors of propositional-languages do-not-understand that the-input is mind-concepts.
· that is why we see expressions like that they represent "entities, concepts, objects, attributes, properties" of the-real-world (domain of discourse).
===
· "the-first" airplanes had movable wings.
· the-same, propositional-languages model the-sentences of human-languages which in-turn are models of conceptual-views.
· we need to model directly the-conceptual-views. [hmnSngo.{2021-02-13}]

name::

lagPpsl.SPECIFIC

description::
* first-order-logic-language,
* ontology-language,

name::
* McsEngl.lagPpsl.specific,

lagPpsl.wikidata

description::
· wikidata-language is a-propositional-language that manages the-data collaborativelly.

">Wikidata data-representation-language:
Wikidata uses a data model called Wikibase, which is a flexible and extensible data model that is designed to be able to represent a wide variety of information. Wikibase is based on the Resource Description Framework (RDF), which is a standard for representing information in a linked data format.

RDF is a graph-based data model that consists of three types of things:
* **Subjects:** Subjects are the things that statements are made about.
* **Predicates:** Predicates are the properties of subjects.
* **Objects:** Objects are the values of predicates.

For example, the following statement represents the fact that Barack Obama is the president of the United States:
* **Subject:** Barack Obama (Q7676)
* **Predicate:** is president of (P31)
* **Object:** United States (Q768)

Wikibase extends RDF with a number of features that make it more suitable for representing the type of information that is stored in Wikidata. These features include:
* **Items:** Items are the entities that are represented in Wikidata. Items can be anything from people and places to events and concepts.
* **Properties:** Properties are the relationships between items. Properties are used to represent the various attributes of items.
* **Statements:** Statements are the assertions that are made about items. Statements are made up of subjects, predicates, and objects.
* **Data types:** Data types are used to specify the type of data that is stored in a property. Wikibase supports a variety of data types, including numbers, dates, and text strings.
* **Qualifiers:** Qualifiers are used to add additional information to statements. Qualifiers can be used to specify the time frame of a statement, the source of a statement, or other relevant information.

Wikibase is a powerful and flexible data model that is well-suited for representing the type of information that is stored in Wikidata. It is a key part of the Wikidata infrastructure, and it is used to store and retrieve data from the Wikidata database.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions."
[{2023-11-18 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/a20753ec7bb9ce20?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.008-wikidata!⇒lagWkdt,
* McsEngl.lagPpsl.wikidata!⇒lagWkdt,
* McsEngl.lagWkdt!=wikidata-lagPpsl,
* McsEngl.wikidata-lagPpsl!⇒lagWkdt,

descriptionLong::
"Wikidata is the free knowledge base that anyone can edit. Just like Wikipedia, Wikidata is built on the MediaWiki wiki package which means that content on pages (just like this one!) can be added, modified, or deleted in collaboration with others. Unlike Wikipedia, Wikidata also uses Wikibase software which allows for collaborative editing of structured data."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Items]
===
"Wikidata is a free, collaborative, multilingual, secondary database, collecting structured data to provide support for Wikipedia, Wikimedia Commons, the other wikis of the Wikimedia movement, and to anyone in the world."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:Introduction]

property of kbWikidata

description::
· a-property is an-attribute-relation.

"A property describes the data value of a statement and can be thought of as a category of data, for example "color" for the data value "blue". Properties, when paired with values, form a statement in Wikidata. Properties are also used in qualifiers.
Properties have their own pages on Wikidata and are connected to items, resulting in a linked data structure."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Properties]
"As opposed to Items, Properties do not refer to Wikipedia pages, but they do specify a Datatype for the data that they (usually) store."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Wikibase/DataModel]

statement of kbWikidata

description::
· Statements describe detailed characteristics of an Item and consist of a property and a value.

name::
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement,
* McsEngl.lagWkdt'output-proposition!⇒Wkdtstatement,
* McsEngl.statement@lagWkdt!⇒Wkdtstatement,

claim of Wkdtstatement

description::
"The core part of a statement without references and ranks is also called claim. A claim without qualifiers is also referred to as snak."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Statements]
"Statements are the main approach of representing factual data, such as the population number in the above example. A Statement consists of two parts: a claim that something is the case (e.g., the claim "Berlin has a population of 3,499,879") and a list of references for that claim (e.g., a publication by the statistical office for Berlin-Brandenburg)."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Wikibase/DataModel]

name::
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement'claim,
* McsEngl.claim@lagWkdt,

snak of Wkdtstatement

description::
"The core part of a statement without references and ranks is also called claim.
A claim without qualifiers is also referred to as snak."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Statements]

name::
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement'snak,
* McsEngl.snak@lagWkdt,

qualifier of Wkdtstatement

description::
· the-other verb-arguments of a-sentence except subject-target.

name::
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement'qualifier,
* McsEngl.qualifier@lagWkdt,

descriptionLong::
"Along with sources and ranks, qualifiers allow statements to be expanded on, annotated, or contextualized beyond what can be expressed in just a simple property-value pair.
Qualifiers are used in order to further describe or refine the value of a property given in a statement. Note that a statement should still provide useful data even without a qualifier; the qualifier is just there to provide additional information.
Like statements and references, qualifiers also consist of a property and a value."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Qualifiers]

references-list of Wkdtstatement

description::
"Statements are the main approach of representing factual data, such as the population number in the above example. A Statement consists of two parts: a claim that something is the case (e.g., the claim "Berlin has a population of 3,499,879") and a list of references for that claim (e.g., a publication by the statistical office for Berlin-Brandenburg).
The reference is given by a ReferenceRecord, and the list of references is allowed to be empty (like in Wikipedia, editors can add Statements without a reference, which might later be improved by others who know about a suitable reference)."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Wikibase/DataModel]

name::
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement'references-list,
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement'source,
* McsEngl.reference@lagWkdt,

descriptionLong::
"The majority of statements on Wikidata should be verifiable, they should be supported by a source of information such as a book, scientific publication, or newspaper article. In Wikidata, references are used to point to specific sources that back up the data provided in a statement.
References, like statements, also consist of at least one property-value pair (for a reference, the value is the source). Typically the property used for sources is one of two options: stated in (P248) (referring to publications and media) and reference URL (P854) (used for websites and online databases)."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Sources]

rank of Wkdtstatement

description::
"References merely state where a data value comes from; ranks indicate what data value is considered the most correct and, by extension, what values should be included in queries.
Ranks are not a way of asserting your view for a disputed value, but instead are used for communicating the consensus opinion for a statement. All disputes should be discussed on the item's discussion page. Edit warring over values is not acceptable.
There is however another way to state that a statement is disputed and by whom: the qualifier statement disputed by (P1310)."
[{2021-01-25} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Ranking]

name::
* McsEngl.Wkdtstatement'rank,

lexeme of kbWikidata

description::
"Lexeme is an entity of Lexicographical data. It contains sense and form sub-entities, but no sitelinks. Instead of a label, a description, and aliases, lexeme entities have a lemma (possibly more than one, for languages with spelling variants), a language, and a lexical category."
[{2023-11-18 retrieved} https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:Glossary#Lexeme]

name::
* McsEngl.kbWikidata'lexeme,
