knowledge-base of lagCycl

description::
"CYC’S KNOWLEDGE BASE:
* 40,000+ Predicates (to express reusable relationships)
* 1,500,000+ Concepts
* 25,000,000+ Explicitly-stated axioms
* Trillions+ Implicit axioms, real-world knowledge"
[{2023-11-14 retrieved} https://cyc.com/platform/]

"The CYC® KB is the repository of Cyc's knowledge. It consists of a large number of FORTs and an even larger number of assertions involving those constants."
[{2021-02-09} http://web.archive.org/web/20121219042246/http://www.cyc.com:80/cycdoc/ref/glossary.html#KB]

name::
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.Cyc!⇒Cyclkb,
* McsEngl.klmrCyc'knowledge-base!⇒Cyclkb,
* McsEngl.Cyclkb,
* McsEngl.lagCycl'knowledge-base!⇒Cyclkb,
* McsEngl.lagCycl'ontology!⇒Cyclkb,
* McsEngl.ontology@lagCycl!⇒Cyclkb,

descriptionLong::
"In philosophy, ontology is the study of being. In knowledge-based systems, an ontology is that part of the system which specifies what things exist and what is true about them. Cyc's ontology is essentially its whole knowledge base. You may hear people refer to their "ontology of devices" or their "temporal ontology". What they are talking about is those parts of their knowledge base (the constants and assertions) that concern devices or time."
[{2021-02-09} http://web.archive.org/web/20121219042246/http://www.cyc.com:80/cycdoc/ref/glossary.html#ontology]

SubL of lagCycl

description::
"SubL is a computer language built by members of Cycorp.
SubL was written to support the Cyc® application, allowing it to run both under Lisp environments and as a C application generated by a SubL-to-C translator"
[{2021-02-09} http://web.archive.org/web/20160822085707/http://www.cyc.com/documentation/subl-reference/]
===
"SubL stands for SubLanguage, and is a computer language created by the CYC® team. It is designed to be easy to translate into C. The entire CYC® application is written in SubL.
Sublisp
An archaic term for SubL."
[{2021-02-09} http://web.archive.org/web/20121219042246/http://www.cyc.com:80/cycdoc/ref/glossary.html#SubL]

Cychmn.Lenat.Doug

description::
"Doug Lenat (President and CEO)
Dr. Douglas B. Lenat is one of the world’s leading computer scientists, and is the founder of the Cyc project and president of Cycorp.
Dr. Lenat has been a Professor of Computer Science at Carnegie-Mellon University and Stanford University and has received numerous honors including:
* Awarded the bi-annual IJCAI Computers and Thought Award which is the highest honor in Artificial Intelligence;
* Named the first Fellow of the AAAI, the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence.
* Fellow of the American Academy for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)
He is a prolific author, whose hundreds of publications include the following books:
* Knowledge Based Systems in Artificial Intelligence (1982, McGraw-Hill)
* Building Expert Systems (1983, Addison-Wesley)
* Knowledge Representation (1988, Addison-Wesley)
* Building Large Knowledge Based Systems (1989, Addison-Wesley)
His 1976 Stanford thesis earned him the bi-annual IJCAI Computers and Thought Award in 1977.
Dr. Lenat received his Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University and his BA and MS in Mathematics from the University of Pennsylvania."
[{2021-02-09} http://web.archive.org/web/20161013223411/http://www.cyc.com:80/about/team/]

name::

evoluting of lagCycl

{2012}-OpenCyc-4.0::
"A version of OpenCyc, 4.0, was released in June 2012. OpenCyc 4.0 included much of the Cyc ontology at that time, containing hundreds of thousands of terms, along with millions of assertions relating the terms to each other; however, these are mainly taxonomic assertions, not the complex rules available in Cyc. The OpenCyc 4.0 knowledge base contained 239,000 concepts and 2,093,000 facts."
[{2021-02-08} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyc#OpenCyc]

{2002}-OpenCyc::
"The first version of OpenCyc was released in spring 2002 and contained only 6,000 concepts and 60,000 facts. The knowledge base was released under the Apache License. Cycorp stated its intention to release OpenCyc under parallel, unrestricted licences to meet the needs of its users. The CycL and SubL interpreter (the program that allows users to browse and edit the database as well as to draw inferences) was released free of charge, but only as a binary, without source code. It was made available for Linux and Microsoft Windows. The open source Texai[15] project released the RDF-compatible content extracted from OpenCyc.[16]"
[{2021-02-08} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyc#OpenCyc]

{1995}-CYC-project-Cycorp::
"Douglas Lenat began the project in July 1984 at MCC, where he was Principal Scientist 1984–1994, and then, since January 1995, has been under active development by the Cycorp company, where he is the CEO."
* McsEngl.{lagCnkl'1995}-Cyc-project-at-Cycorp,
[{2021-02-10} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyc]

{1989}-lagCycl-HOL::
"By 1989,[6] CycL had expanded in expressive power to Higher Order Logic (HOL)."
[{2021-02-10} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyc]

{1984}-CYC-project::
"Doug Lenat's CYC (from enCYClopedia) Project at MCC in Austin, a ten-year $35 million project begun in 1984, uses logic, too, but emphasizes the Aristotle-problem, employing a dozen 'ontological engineers' to enumerate tens of millions of common-sense facts that will ultimately 'add up' to logical intelligence. Lenat's goal is a system that can understand and speak ordinary language, and detect violations of common sense as readily as humans can."
[{2021-02-08} http://sandcastle.cosc.brocku.ca/~bross/3P71/misc/outsider_ai.txt-{1995-12-26}]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-lagCycl,
* McsEngl.lagCycl'evoluting,

lagCycl.SPECIFIC

description::
"Every representation is a trade-off between expressiveness (how easily you can say complicated things) and efficiency (how easily the machine can reason with what you've told it).
English is very expressive but not very efficient.
Most computer languages, such as Basic, C, and Fortran, are efficient but not very expressive.
To get both qualities, we separated the epistemological problem (what should the system know?) from the heuristic problem (how can it effectively reason with what it knows?) and developed two separate languages, respectively EL and HL.
Our knowledge enterers talk to CYC in the clean, expressive language (EL).
Their input is then converted into the heuristic language (HL), which is efficient for dealing with many sorts of frequently recurring inference problems, such as reasoning about time, causality, containment, and so forth."
[{2021-02-12} http://web.archive.org/web/20001208155800/http://www.cyc.com/halslegacy.html]

name::
* McsEngl.lagCycl.specific,

lagCycl.expressive

description::
"Every representation is a trade-off between expressiveness (how easily you can say complicated things) and efficiency (how easily the machine can reason with what you've told it).
English is very expressive but not very efficient.
Most computer languages, such as Basic, C, and Fortran, are efficient but not very expressive.
To get both qualities, we separated the epistemological problem (what should the system know?) from the heuristic problem (how can it effectively reason with what it knows?) and developed two separate languages, respectively EL and HL.
Our knowledge enterers talk to CYC in the clean, expressive language (EL).
Their input is then converted into the heuristic language (HL), which is efficient for dealing with many sorts of frequently recurring inference problems, such as reasoning about time, causality, containment, and so forth."
[{2021-02-12} http://web.archive.org/web/20001208155800/http://www.cyc.com/halslegacy.html]

name::
* McsEngl.lagCycl.EL'(expressive-language),
* McsEngl.lagCycl.expressive,

descriptionLong::
"Epistemological level refers to the way knowledge is expressed when CYC® communicates with users or external programs. This stands in contrast with heuristic level, which refers to the way knowledge is actually stored, and inference implemented, in CYC®."
[{2021-02-12} http://web.archive.org/web/20121219042246/http://www.cyc.com:80/cycdoc/ref/glossary.html#EL]

lagCycl.heuristic

description::
"Every representation is a trade-off between expressiveness (how easily you can say complicated things) and efficiency (how easily the machine can reason with what you've told it).
English is very expressive but not very efficient.
Most computer languages, such as Basic, C, and Fortran, are efficient but not very expressive.
To get both qualities, we separated the epistemological problem (what should the system know?) from the heuristic problem (how can it effectively reason with what it knows?) and developed two separate languages, respectively EL and HL.
Our knowledge enterers talk to CYC in the clean, expressive language (EL).
Their input is then converted into the heuristic language (HL), which is efficient for dealing with many sorts of frequently recurring inference problems, such as reasoning about time, causality, containment, and so forth."
[{2021-02-12} http://web.archive.org/web/20001208155800/http://www.cyc.com/halslegacy.html]

name::
* McsEngl.lagCycl.HL'(heuristic-language),
* McsEngl.lagCycl.heuristic,

descriptionLong::
"heuristic level (HL)
Another name for this might be "implementation level". Heuristic level refers to the way knowledge is actually stored, and inference implemented, in CYC®. This stands in contrast to the Epistemological Level (EL), which refers to the way knowledge is expressed when CYC® communicates with users or external programs."
[{2021-02-12} http://web.archive.org/web/20121219042246/http://www.cyc.com:80/cycdoc/ref/glossary.html#HL]

lagKnlg.ontology-language

description::
× generic: logo--knowledge-language,

"In computer science and artificial intelligence, ontology languages are formal languages used to construct ontologies. They allow the encoding of knowledge about specific domains and often include reasoning rules that support the processing of that knowledge. Ontology languages are usually declarative languages, are almost always generalizations of frame languages, and are commonly based on either first-order logic or on description logic."
[{2021-01-26} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontology_language]

name::
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.010-ontology-language!⇒lagOntg,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.ontology-language!⇒lagOntg,
* McsEngl.lagOntg!=ONToloGy-language,
* McsEngl.lagPpsl.ontology-language!⇒lagOntg,
* McsEngl.ontology-language!⇒lagOntg,

descriptionLong::
"overview of ontology-languages:
Ontology languages are formal systems designed to represent and define concepts, entities, and their relationships in a structured and machine-readable way. They are essential in knowledge representation, artificial intelligence, semantic web development, and various other fields. Here's an overview of some prominent ontology languages:

1. **RDF (Resource Description Framework):** RDF is a basic framework for expressing relationships between resources in a triple format (subject-predicate-object). It forms the foundation of the Semantic Web.

2. **OWL (Web Ontology Language):** OWL is a family of knowledge representation languages used to create ontologies. There are three versions: OWL Lite, OWL DL, and OWL Full, each with different levels of expressiveness.

3. **RDFS (Resource Description Framework Schema):** RDFS is an extension of RDF that allows for the definition of classes and properties, enabling basic ontology modeling.

4. **SHACL (Shapes Constraint Language):** SHACL is a language for defining constraints on RDF graphs. It's used to ensure that RDF data adheres to specific structural and semantic rules.

5. **SKOS (Simple Knowledge Organization System):** SKOS is a model for expressing knowledge organization systems like thesauri, taxonomies, and classification schemes. It's particularly useful in libraries and semantic web applications.

6. **Common Logic:** Common Logic is a family of logic-based ontology languages that provides a high level of expressiveness. It's commonly used in formal knowledge representation.

7. **Description Logics:** Description logics are a family of logic-based ontology languages that underlie OWL. They provide a way to model and reason about concepts and their relationships with high expressiveness and scalability.

8. **RIF (Rule Interchange Format):** RIF is a family of languages for expressing rules that can be used in combination with ontology languages to add automated reasoning to knowledge systems.

9. **Topic Maps:** Topic Maps are a standard for representing information about the relationships between concepts, representing knowledge in a highly flexible and interconnected manner.

10. **Protege:** While not a formal ontology language itself, Protege is a popular ontology development platform that supports various ontology languages, including OWL and RDF, and provides tools for ontology editing, visualization, and reasoning.

These ontology languages and frameworks help to formalize and structure knowledge for machine processing, enabling the development of intelligent systems, data integration, and semantic interoperability. They are widely used in fields such as the Semantic Web, artificial intelligence, knowledge engineering, and more to model complex domains and enable automated reasoning and data integration."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/b772e8ef-c6be-489f-8ad4-69895bc95406]

"Ontology languages are formal languages used to construct ontologies. Ontologies are a formal way to describe taxonomies and classification networks, essentially defining the structure of knowledge for various domains: the nouns representing classes of objects and the verbs representing relations between the objects.

Ontology languages are typically based on logic, which allows for the expression of complex relationships between concepts and the inference of new knowledge from existing knowledge. This makes them well-suited for a variety of applications, including:
* Knowledge representation and sharing: Ontologies can be used to represent and share knowledge about a wide range of domains, such as medicine, biology, engineering, and finance.
* Data integration: Ontologies can be used to integrate data from different sources, making it easier to find and use the data.
* Semantic search: Ontologies can be used to improve the accuracy and relevance of semantic search results.
* Artificial intelligence: Ontologies can be used to develop more intelligent AI systems that can reason about the world and make decisions based on their knowledge.

Some of the most popular ontology languages include:
* **Web Ontology Language (OWL)**: OWL is a family of knowledge representation languages for authoring ontologies. It is the most widely used ontology language, and is supported by a wide range of tools and software.
* **Resource Description Framework (RDF)**: RDF is a lightweight, flexible framework for representing information and its relationships. It is often used to represent ontologies in a machine-readable format.
* **RDF Schema (RDFS)**: RDFS is an extension of RDF that provides additional vocabulary for describing ontologies. It can be used to define simple ontologies, or to provide additional information about OWL ontologies.

Other ontology languages include:
* **Description Logic (DL)**: DL is a family of formal languages used to represent knowledge in a structured way. DL languages are often used as the basis for ontology languages, such as OWL.
* **Concept Language (CL)**: CL is a simple ontology language that is easy to learn and use. It is often used for educational purposes, or for developing small ontologies.
* **Knowledge Interchange Format (KIF)**: KIF is a general-purpose knowledge representation language that can be used to represent ontologies. It is often used for research purposes, or for developing ontologies for complex domains.

Ontology languages are a powerful tool for representing and sharing knowledge. They are used in a wide range of applications, including knowledge representation and sharing, data integration, semantic search, and artificial intelligence."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} http://localhost/dWstSgm/dirMcs/dirTchInf/McsTchInf000039.last.html#idLKnlg010]

input of lagOntg

description::
· the-info we want to map with lagOntg.

name::
* McsEngl.lagOntg'input,

output|ontology of lagOntg

description::
"Ontologies are formalized vocabularies of terms, often covering a specific domain and shared by a community of users.
They specify the definitions of terms by describing their relationships with other terms in the ontology."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/TR/owl2-overview/]

· a-model that maps the-input.
· ontology I call the-outermost system that models an-input.

"In science and information science, an ontology formally represents knowledge as a set of concepts within a domain, and the relationships between those concepts."
[{2023-08-23 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_science#Ontology]

name::
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.ontology!⇒kbOnto,
* McsEngl.kbOnto!=ontology--knowledge-base,
* McsEngl.lagOntg'output!⇒kbOnto,
* McsEngl.lagOntg'ontology!⇒kbOnto,
* McsEngl.ontology!⇒kbOnto,

descriptionLong::
"In information science a conceptualization is an abstract simplified view of some selected part of the world, containing the objects, concepts, and other entities that are presumed of interest for some particular purpose and the relationships between them.[2][3] An explicit specification of a conceptualization is an ontology, and it may occur that a conceptualization can be realized by several distinct ontologies.[2]"
[{2021-01-27} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conceptualization_(information_science)]
· the-above text shows the-confusion on what a-concept is and consequently an-ontology.
===
"overview of ontology:
An ontology is a formal and explicit representation of concepts, categories, properties, and their relationships within a specific domain of knowledge. Ontologies are used in various fields, including philosophy, computer science, artificial intelligence, and information science, to facilitate knowledge sharing, data integration, and reasoning. Here's an overview of ontologies:

1. **Conceptual Framework:** At its core, an ontology serves as a conceptual framework for representing knowledge. It defines the key concepts in a domain, such as objects, actions, and their properties, and the relationships between them.

2. **Formal Representation:** Ontologies are typically represented using a formal language, often based on logic or semantic web standards. This formal representation allows for precise and unambiguous definitions of concepts and their interconnections.

3. **Hierarchy:** Many ontologies include a hierarchical structure where concepts are organized in a tree-like fashion. This hierarchy allows for the categorization and classification of concepts, with more general concepts at the top and more specific ones at lower levels.

4. **Attributes and Properties:** Ontologies define attributes or properties associated with concepts. These attributes can describe characteristics, relationships, and constraints related to the concepts in the domain.

5. **Relationships:** Relationships between concepts in an ontology capture how they are connected or related to each other. Common relationship types include "is-a" (taxonomy or subclass relationships) and "part-of" relationships.

6. **Axioms and Constraints:** Ontologies often include axioms and constraints that specify rules governing the domain. These rules can express logical relationships, restrictions, and inferences.

7. **Standardization:** In many cases, ontologies adhere to standardized ontology languages and frameworks, such as the Web Ontology Language (OWL) for the Semantic Web. This helps ensure interoperability and consistency in ontology development and usage.

8. **Domain Specificity:** Ontologies can be domain-specific, addressing a particular area of knowledge, or more general, covering broader topics. For example, there are ontologies for medical terminology, geography, and even abstract concepts like time and space.

9. **Knowledge Sharing:** Ontologies facilitate knowledge sharing and data integration, as they provide a common vocabulary and structure that can be understood and used by both humans and machines. This is particularly valuable in information retrieval, data integration, and knowledge representation.

10. **Reasoning and Inference:** Ontologies support automated reasoning and inference. By applying logical rules and axioms, software systems can derive new knowledge or make deductions based on the existing ontology.

11. **Applications:** Ontologies are used in various applications, including semantic web technologies, information retrieval, natural language processing, expert systems, data integration, and more.

12. **Evolution and Maintenance:** Ontologies can evolve over time to accommodate changes in knowledge or domain understanding. Maintenance and version control are important considerations in ontology development.

Overall, ontologies play a critical role in knowledge management and knowledge representation. They provide a structured way to organize and capture knowledge, making it accessible, shareable, and interpretable by both humans and machines, and they are a fundamental component of many AI and data-related applications."
[{2023-10-20 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/0af0bd57-e782-489f-b9bc-9c0c7fe8cd01]

doing of ontology

* alignment-of-ontology,

name::
* McsEngl.kbOnto'doing,

creation of ontology

description::
"Ontology learning (ontology extraction, ontology generation, or ontology acquisition) is the automatic or semi-automatic creation of ontologies, including extracting the corresponding domain's terms and the relationships between the concepts that these terms represent from a corpus of natural language text, and encoding them with an ontology language for easy retrieval. As building ontologies manually is extremely labor-intensive and time-consuming, there is great motivation to automate the process.
Typically, the process starts by extracting terms and concepts or noun phrases from plain text using linguistic processors such as part-of-speech tagging and phrase chunking. Then statistical[1] or symbolic[2][3] techniques are used to extract relation signatures, often based on pattern-based[4] or definition-based[5] hypernym extraction techniques."
[{2021-01-27} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontology_learning]

name::
* McsEngl.kbOnto'building,
* McsEngl.kbOnto'creation,
* McsEngl.kbOnto'generation,

alignment of ontology

description::
"Ontology alignment, or ontology matching, is the process of determining correspondences between concepts in ontologies. A set of correspondences is also called an alignment. The phrase takes on a slightly different meaning, in computer science, cognitive science or philosophy."
[{2021-01-27} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontology_alignment]

name::
* McsEngl.kbOnto'alignment,
* McsEngl.kbOnto'matching,

evoluting of ontology

description::
">evolution of ontologies:
The evolution of ontologies is closely tied to the development of information technologies, artificial intelligence, and the need for effective knowledge representation and sharing. Ontologies have their roots in philosophy, particularly in the field of metaphysics, where they are used to describe the nature of existence and the relationships between different entities. In the context of information science and computer science, ontologies serve as formal frameworks for organizing knowledge and providing a common understanding of a domain.

Here's a brief overview of the evolution of ontologies:
1. **Early Philosophical Roots (Ancient to Early Modern Periods):** The term "ontology" itself comes from philosophy, where it has been used to discuss the nature of being and existence. Philosophers like Aristotle explored categorization and classification of entities, laying the groundwork for later developments in ontology.

2. **Knowledge Representation in AI (1960s-1980s):** As artificial intelligence (AI) emerged as a field, there was a growing need for systems to represent and reason about knowledge. Early AI systems used simple knowledge representation languages, but the limitations became apparent as the complexity of information increased.

3. **Semantic Web and RDF (1990s):** The concept of the Semantic Web, introduced by Tim Berners-Lee, envisioned a web where information could be easily shared and understood by machines. Resource Description Framework (RDF) and RDF Schema (RDFS) were developed to create a framework for describing resources and their relationships.

4. **Ontology Languages and OWL (1990s-2000s):** The Web Ontology Language (OWL) emerged as a standard for creating ontologies, providing a more expressive and formalized way to represent knowledge. OWL allows for richer modeling of relationships and supports reasoning capabilities.

5. **Application in Biomedicine and Bioinformatics (2000s-Present):** Ontologies found significant applications in domains like biomedicine and bioinformatics. The Gene Ontology (GO) and other biomedical ontologies were developed to facilitate the integration and sharing of biological knowledge.

6. **Industry Adoption and Standardization (2000s-Present):** Ontologies gained traction in various industries, including finance, manufacturing, and government. Standardization bodies like the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) played a crucial role in establishing common ontological frameworks.

7. **Linked Data and Knowledge Graphs (2010s-Present):** The idea of Linked Data, championed by Tim Berners-Lee, involves creating a web of interlinked data using standard formats. Knowledge graphs, which leverage ontologies, became popular for organizing and connecting information in diverse domains.

8. **Machine Learning and Ontologies (2010s-Present):** Machine learning techniques, particularly in natural language processing and knowledge graph embedding, have been integrated with ontologies to enhance their usability and extraction of implicit knowledge.

The evolution of ontologies continues as new technologies and methodologies, such as knowledge graphs, graph databases, and advances in AI, contribute to their development and application in various domains. The ongoing research and practical applications are likely to shape the future trajectory of ontologies."
[{2023-11-14 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/ef1e1310-5cf5-4022-bd84-4b06cbfe7221]

name::
* McsEngl.kbOnto'evolution,

ontology.formal

description::
"In information science an ontology is formal if it is specified in a formal language, otherwise it is informal.
In philosophy, a separate distinction between formal and nonformal ontologies exists, which does not relate to the use of a formal language."
[{2023-11-17 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_ontology#Formal_versus_nonformal]

ontology.axiomatized

description::
"axiomatized ontology overview:
An axiomatized ontology is a formal representation of a domain of knowledge that is explicitly defined by a set of axioms. Axioms are statements that express the relationships between different concepts in the domain. By explicitly stating these relationships, axiomatized ontologies provide a precise and unambiguous way to share and reason about knowledge.

**Components of an Axiomatized Ontology**
An axiomatized ontology typically consists of the following components:
1. **Classes:** These represent the main categories of entities in the domain. For example, in a medical ontology, classes might include "Patient", "Disease", and "Medication".
2. **Properties:** These represent the attributes of classes. For example, the class "Patient" might have properties such as "name", "age", and "medical history".
3. **Relations:** These represent the relationships between classes. For example, the class "Patient" might have relations such as "has_diagnosis" and "is_taking_medication".
4. **Axioms:** These are statements that express the relationships between classes, properties, and relations. For example, an axiom might state that all patients have a name.

**Benefits of Axiomatized Ontologies**
Axiomatized ontologies offer several benefits, including:
1. **Formalization:** They provide a precise and unambiguous way to represent knowledge.
2. **Sharing:** They can be easily shared between different systems and applications.
3. **Reasoning:** They can be used to reason about knowledge and infer new information.
4. **Interoperability:** They can facilitate communication and data exchange between different systems.

**Applications of Axiomatized Ontologies**
Axiomatized ontologies are used in a wide variety of applications, including:
1. **Knowledge representation:** They are used to represent knowledge in semantic web applications, knowledge bases, and expert systems.
2. **Information retrieval:** They are used to improve the precision and recall of information retrieval systems.
3. **Natural language processing:** They are used to improve the understanding and generation of natural language.
4. **Data integration:** They are used to integrate data from different sources.

**Example of an Axiomatized Ontology**
The Gene Ontology (GO) is an example of a well-known axiomatized ontology. It is a structured vocabulary of genes and proteins that are involved in biological processes. The GO is used by biologists around the world to annotate their data and share their knowledge.

**Conclusion**
Axiomatized ontologies are a powerful tool for representing, sharing, and reasoning about knowledge. They are used in a wide variety of applications and are becoming increasingly important as the amount of data in the world grows."
[{2023-11-17 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/d910fbd0b744152f?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.axiomatized-ontology!⇒ontologyAxiom,
* McsEngl.ontologyAxiom,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.axiomatized!⇒ontologyAxiom,

ontology.upper

description::
"Upper ontologies (top-level or foundational ontologies) represent universal concepts and properties, independent from single scientific fields, such as event, space, time, dimension, substance, phenomenon, identity, process, quantity, etc., on which a general consensus of large user communities should be achieved. The main aim of foundational ontologies is to allow multiple artificial agents to cooperate with each other and with humans. To achieve this, foundational ontologies “negotiate meaning” and help for “establishing consensus in a mixed society” (Gangemi et al. 2002)."
[{2021-01-26} https://www.isko.org/cyclo/ontologies#5]

name::
* McsEngl.foundational-ontology!⇒ontologyUpper,
* McsEngl.general-ontology!⇒ontologyUpper,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.upper!⇒ontologyUpper,
* McsEngl.ontologyUpper,
* McsEngl.top-level-ontology!⇒ontologyUpper,
* McsEngl.upper-ontology!⇒ontologyUpper,

ontologyUpper.UMBEL-{2008-2016}

description::
"Upper Mapping and Binding Exchange Layer (UMBEL) is an ontology of 28,000 reference concepts that maps to a simplified subset of the OpenCyc ontology, that is intended to provide a way of linking the precise OpenCyc ontology with less formal ontologies.[29] It also has formal mappings to Wikipedia, DBpedia, PROTON and GeoNames. It has been developed and maintained as open source by Structured Dynamics."
[{2023-11-14 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_ontology#UMBEL]

* McsEngl.ontgUmbel,
* McsEngl.ontologyUpper.UMBEL,

ontologyUpper.SUMO-{2004-2007}

description::
">example of Suggested-Upper-Merged-Ontology:
The Suggested Upper Merged Ontology (SUMO) is a large, high-level ontology intended to provide a common foundation for a variety of knowledge-based systems. It is designed to be as general and domain-independent as possible, and it covers a wide range of topics, including:
* **Entities:** Things that exist, such as objects, events, processes, and states.
* **Relations:** Relationships between entities, such as is-a, part-of, and cause-of.
* **Attributes:** Properties of entities, such as color, size, and location.
* **Axioms:** Rules that constrain the relationships and attributes of entities.

SUMO is written in the SUO-KIF language, a higher-order logic that has a LISP-like syntax. It is also available in the TPTP family of languages. A mapping from WordNet synsets to SUMO has been defined.

SUMO is intended to be used as a foundation ontology for a variety of computer information processing systems. It can be used to:
* **Improve the interoperability of different knowledge bases:** SUMO can provide a common vocabulary and set of relationships that can be used to bridge the gap between different knowledge bases. This can make it easier to share and reuse knowledge.
* **Support automated reasoning:** SUMO can be used to reason about the relationships between entities in a knowledge base. This can be used to make inferences, answer questions, and solve problems.
* **Develop natural language processing systems:** SUMO can be used to develop natural language processing systems that can understand and generate text that is semantically consistent with the ontology.

SUMO is a valuable resource for anyone who is interested in developing knowledge-based systems. It is a well-defined, comprehensive ontology that can be used to improve the interoperability, reasoning capabilities, and natural language processing capabilities of a wide range of systems.

Here is an example of how SUMO can be used to represent the knowledge about a dog:
```
(instance dog (isa animal))
(instance dog (has-part tail))
(instance dog (has-part fur))
(instance dog (can bark))
```

This code states that dog is an instance of animal, that dog has-part tail, that dog has-part fur, and that dog can bark. This is just a small example of how SUMO can be used to represent a wide range of knowledge."
[{2023-11-16 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/1b8854012490f002?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.SUMO,
* McsEngl.SUMO!=Suggested-Upper-Merged-Ontology,

* McsEngl.ontologyUpper.SUMO,

info-resource of SUMO

description::

ontologyUpper.GFO-{1999-2008}

description::
">example of General formal ontology
The General Formal Ontology (GFO) is a top-level ontology that provides a general framework for representing common-sense knowledge about the world. It is a large and complex ontology that includes a wide range of concepts, such as objects, processes, properties, relations, roles, functions, facts, and situations.

Here are some examples of how GFO can be used to represent common-sense knowledge:
* **Objects:** GFO can be used to represent objects such as cars, books, and people. It can also be used to represent more abstract objects such as ideas, emotions, and events.
* **Processes:** GFO can be used to represent processes such as running, eating, and thinking. It can also be used to represent more abstract processes such as learning, growing, and changing.
* **Properties:** GFO can be used to represent properties of objects such as color, shape, and size. It can also be used to represent properties of processes such as duration, speed, and intensity.
* **Relations:** GFO can be used to represent relations between objects such as is-a, part-of, and located-in. It can also be used to represent relations between processes such as precedes, causes, and enables.
* **Roles:** GFO can be used to represent roles that entities can play in situations. For example, a person can play the role of a teacher, a student, or a parent.
* **Functions:** GFO can be used to represent functions that entities perform. For example, a heart has the function of pumping blood, and a brain has the function of processing information.
* **Facts:** GFO can be used to represent facts about the world. For example, the fact that the Earth is round can be represented in GFO.
* **Situations:** GFO can be used to represent situations that occur in the world. For example, a game of football is a situation that involves players, a ball, and a set of rules.

GFO is a powerful tool for representing common-sense knowledge. It can be used to develop a wide range of applications, such as knowledge bases, semantic web applications, and natural language processing systems.

Here is an example of how GFO can be used to represent the fact that "John is a student":
```
John: Individual
John: is-a: Student

Student: Class
Student: is-a: Person
```

This representation states that John is an individual and that he is an instance of the class Student. The class Student is a subclass of the class Person, which means that all students are also people.

GFO is a complex ontology, and it can be difficult to learn. However, there are a number of resources available to help you learn GFO, including online documentation, tutorials, and courses."
[{2023-11-16 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/3662dbfecdb0a15d?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.GFO!=general-formal-ontology,
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.GFO,
* McsEngl.ontgGfo,
* McsEngl.ontologyUpper.GFO,

ontologyUpper.YAMATO-{1999-2023}

description::
">evolution of Yet Another More Advanced Top Ontology:
YAMATO (Yet Another More Advanced Top-level Ontology) is a foundational ontology that has been under development since 1999. It is designed to be a comprehensive and rigorous framework for representing common-sense knowledge about the world. YAMATO has been used in a variety of applications, including medical informatics, learning engineering, and knowledge engineering.

The evolution of YAMATO can be divided into three phases:
* **Phase 1 (1999-2005):** This phase focused on developing the core concepts of the ontology, such as the concepts of entity, event, process, and quality.
* **Phase 2 (2006-2010):** This phase focused on refining the ontology and adding new concepts, such as the concept of role.
* **Phase 3 (2011-present):** This phase has focused on applying YAMATO to real-world applications and developing tools and methods for using the ontology.

Here is a more detailed timeline of the evolution of YAMATO:
* **1999:** YAMATO is first developed by Riichiro Mizoguchi.
* **2005:** Mizoguchi publishes his book "Ontological Engineering", which provides a detailed exposition of the philosophical underpinnings of YAMATO.
* **2006:** YAMATO is used to develop the first ontology of learning and instructional theories.
* **2008:** YAMATO is used to develop a medical ontology.
* **2009:** YAMATO is used to develop an ontology of genomics.
* **2010:** YAMATO is implemented with the ontology editor Hozo and in OWL.
* **2011:** YAMATO is used to model the behavior of mobile users.
* **2012:** YAMATO is used to develop a functional ontology.
* **2013:** YAMATO is used to develop a knowledge management system for a large enterprise.
* **2014:** YAMATO is used to develop a semantic search engine.
* **2015:** YAMATO is used to develop a natural language processing system.
* **2016:** YAMATO is used to develop a machine translation system.
* **2017:** YAMATO is used to develop a chatbot.
* **2018:** YAMATO is used to develop a virtual assistant.
* **2019:** YAMATO is used to develop a recommendation system.
* **2020:** YAMATO is used to develop a personalized learning system.
* **2021:** YAMATO is used to develop a decision support system.
* **2022:** YAMATO is used to develop a risk assessment system.
* **2023:** YAMATO continues to be developed and applied in a wide range of applications.

The evolution of YAMATO reflects the growing importance of ontologies in a variety of fields. As ontologies become more sophisticated and widely used, YAMATO is likely to continue to play a leading role in the development of the Semantic Web."
[{2023-11-14 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/73ecc67ce66ce5dc?hl=en&pli=1]

* McsEngl.ontologyUpper.YAMATO,

ontologyUpperNo.disease-ontology

description::
× webaddress: https://www.disease-ontology.org/do,

"The Disease Ontology (DO) is a formal ontology of human disease.[1][2][3] The Disease Ontology project is hosted at the Institute for Genome Sciences at the University of Maryland School of Medicine.

The Disease Ontology project was initially developed in 2003 at Northwestern University to address the need for a purpose-built ontology that covers the full spectrum of disease concepts annotated within biomedical repositories within an ontological framework that is extensible to meet community needs.

The Disease Ontology is an OBO (Open Biomedical Ontologies) Foundry ontology.

Disease Ontology Identifiers (DOIDs) consist of the prefix DOID: followed by number, for example, Alzheimer's disease has the stable identifier DOID:10652. DO is cross-referenced in several resources such as UniProt.

Example term
The Disease Ontology entry for motor neuron disease in OBO format is given below, showing the links to other classification schemes, including ICD-9, ICD-10, MeSH, SNOMED and UMLS.

id: DOID:231
name: motor neuron disease
def: "A neurodegenerative disease that is located_in the motor neurones." Motor neuron disease
xref: ICD10CM:G12.2
xref: ICD10CM:G12.20
xref: ICD9CM:335.2
xref: MSH:D016472
xref: SNOMEDCT_US_2016_03_01:155015007
xref: SNOMEDCT_US_2016_03_01:192888001
xref: SNOMEDCT_US_2016_03_01:192889009
xref: SNOMEDCT_US_2016_03_01:192890000
xref: SNOMEDCT_US_2016_03_01:37340000
xref: UMLS_CUI:C0085084
is_a: DOID:1289 ! Neurodegenerative disease"
[{2023-11-17 retrieved} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease_Ontology]

* McsEngl.ontgDisease,
* McsEngl.ontologyUpperNo.disease-ontology,

ontology.4D

description::
"4D-ontology overview:
4D-ontology is an ontology that represents the world as a collection of 4D entities, each of which has a spatial extent and a temporal extent. This is in contrast to traditional 3D ontologies, which represent the world as a collection of 3D entities, each of which has only a spatial extent.

4D-ontologies are useful for representing the world in a way that is more realistic and intuitive. They are also more expressive than 3D ontologies, and they can be used to represent a wider range of phenomena.

There are two main types of 4D-ontology: perdurantism and endurantism. Perdurantists believe that objects extend through time and change their properties over time. Endurantists believe that objects exist at each point in time and do not change their properties.

4D-ontologies have a number of advantages over traditional 3D ontologies. They are more realistic and intuitive, they are more expressive, and they can be used to represent a wider range of phenomena.

However, 4D-ontologies also have a number of disadvantages. They are more complex than traditional 3D ontologies, and they can be more difficult to implement.

4D-ontologies are still under development, but they have the potential to be a powerful tool for representing the world.

Here are some of the key differences between 3D and 4D ontologies:
* In a 3D ontology, an object is represented as a single entity that exists at a single point in time.
* In a 4D ontology, an object is represented as a collection of entities, each of which exists at a different point in time.
* 3D ontologies are typically used to represent static objects.
* 4D ontologies are typically used to represent dynamic objects.
* 3D ontologies are typically less expressive than 4D ontologies.
* 4D ontologies are typically more complex than 3D ontologies.

Overall, 4D-ontologies are a more powerful and expressive way of representing the world than 3D ontologies. However, they are also more complex and difficult to implement.

Here are some of the benefits of using 4D-ontologies:
* They are more realistic and intuitive than 3D ontologies.
* They are more expressive than 3D ontologies.
* They can be used to represent a wider range of phenomena.

Here are some of the challenges of using 4D-ontologies:
* They are more complex than 3D ontologies.
* They can be more difficult to implement.
* They are still under development.

Despite these challenges, 4D-ontologies have the potential to be a powerful tool for representing the world. They are already being used in a number of applications, and their use is likely to grow in the future."
[{2023-11-17 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/2afda959bcca6254?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.4D-ontology,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.4D,

ontology.bibliographic

description::
"A particular attention must be paid to bibliographic ontologies, which enable the description of entities that belong to the bibliographic set, such as textual publications (e.g., articles, monographs, and series) and web pages, datasets, films etc., and define the relationships among these bibliographic entities (Nurmikko-Fuller et al. 2015; 2016). Besides, bibliographic ontologies have been built to define specific relationships, such as authorship, editorship, and aboutness among entities, as well as the relationships that connect → works (Smiraglia 2019) and their abridgments, adaptations, and translations. They can underline the relationships between a serial and the transformations it may have had over time, such as supplements or successors."
[{2021-01-26} https://www.isko.org/cyclo/ontologies#6.1]

name::
* McsEngl.bibliographic-ontology,
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.bibliographic,
* McsEngl.ontgBibliographic,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.bibliographic,

ontology.biomedical

description::
"In biological and medical domain, controlled vocabularies of terms and relations are used to share information and several domain ontologies have been developed. A consortium of ontology developers — The Open Biological and Biomedical Ontology (OBO) Foundry — was founded in 2001 to define shared principles for developing interoperable ontologies in biomedicine. The principles include the collaborative development of ontologies and the use of a common syntax (RDF/XML); use based on most prominent models such as the Gene Ontology; and the provision of open access. The library of ontologies encompasses the BFO upper ontology and domain ontologies such as the Gene Ontology, the Disease Ontology, the Plant Ontology, the Protein Ontology, the Cell Ontology, the Coronavirus Ontology and so on. The Gene Ontology (GO), developed in 1998, describes the biological domain considering three aspects: cellular components, that is, the parts of the cell; biological processes, such as chemical reactions or metabolism; and molecular functions. Thus, the GO consists of three ontologies, each one devoted to one aspect. The GO is a dynamic vocabulary that allows description of the functions and activities performed by the gene products, that is, the macromolecules, across different organisms, enabling the analysis of genomic data. The three ontologies may be used to query a database of gene product functions."
[{2021-01-26} https://www.isko.org/cyclo/ontologies#6.3]

name::
* McsEngl.biomedical-ontology,
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.biomedical,
* McsEngl.ontgBiomedical,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.biomedical,

BioPortal of ontology.biomedical

description::
* https://bioportal.bioontology.org/,
* http://data.bioontology.org/property_search?q=has%20dimension,
===
"BioPortal provides access to commonly used biomedical ontologies and to tools for working with them. BioPortal allows you to
* browse the library of ontologies
* search for a term across multiple ontologies
* browse mappings between terms in different ontologies
* receive recommendations on which ontologies are most relevant for a corpus
* annotate text with terms from ontologies
* search biomedical resources for a term
* browse a selection of projects that use BioPortal resources
All information available through the BioPortal Web site is also available through the NCBO Web service REST API."
[{2021-02-01} https://www.bioontology.org/wiki/BioPortal_Help]

name::
* McsEngl.BioPortal,

Χ Classes, 9,708,407
Χ Properties, 36,286
Χ Mappings, 78,104,619
[{2021-02-01} https://bioportal.bioontology.org/]

ontology.foaf

description::
"One of the first RDF vocabularies used worldwide was the "Friend of a Friend" (FOAF) vocabulary for describing social networks."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/NOTE-rdf11-primer-20140624/#section-vocabulary]

name::
* McsEngl.FOAF-Rdfvoc!⇒foaf,
* McsEngl.Rdfvoc.FOAF!⇒foaf,
* McsEngl.friend-of-a-friend-vocabulary!⇒foaf,
* McsEngl.foaf!=friend-of-a-friend-vocabulary,
