foaf:geekcode-property::
Χ sDescription: geekcode - A textual geekcode for this person, see http://www.geekcode.com/geek.html
Χ sSource-url: http://xmlns.com/foaf/spec/20140114.html#term_geekcode
Χ sStatus: archaic
Χ sDomain: having this property implies being a Person
Χ rdfs:isDefinedBy: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/

Χ sDescriptionLong: The geekcode property is used to represent a 'Geek Code' for some Person,
See the Wikipedia entry for details of the code, which provides a somewhat frivolous and willfully obscure mechanism for characterising technical expertise, interests and habits. The geekcode property is not bound to any particular version of the code.
* McsEngl.foaf/geekcode,
* McsEngl.geekcode@foaf,

foaf:givenname-property::
Χ sDescription: Given name - The given name of some person,
Χ sSource-url: http://xmlns.com/foaf/spec/20140114.html#term_givenname
Χ sStatus: archaic
Χ rdfs:isDefinedBy: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/

Χ sDescriptionLong: The givenName property is provided (alongside familyName) for use when describing parts of people's names. Although these concepts do not capture the full range of personal naming styles found world-wide, they are commonly used and have some value,
There is also a simple name property.
Support is also provided for the more archaic and culturally varying terminology of firstName and lastName.
See the issue tracker for design discussions, status and ongoing work on rationalising the FOAF naming machinery.
* McsEngl.foaf/givenname,
* McsEngl.givenname@foaf,

foaf:holdsAccount-property::
Χ sDescription: account - Indicates an account held by this agent,
Χ sSource-url: http://xmlns.com/foaf/spec/20140114.html#term_holdsAccount
Χ sStatus: archaic
Χ sDomain: having this property implies being a Agent
Χ sRange: every value of this property is a OnlineAccount
Χ rdfs:isDefinedBy: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/

Χ sDescriptionLong:
Χ editorial: This property is considered archaic usage. It is generally better to use account instead,
The holdsAccount property relates a Agent to an OnlineAccount for which they are the sole account holder. See OnlineAccount for usage details.
This property is equivalent to the account property, which was introduced primarily to provide simpler naming for the same idea.
* McsEngl.foaf/holdsAccount,
* McsEngl.holdsAccount@foaf,

foaf:surname-property::
Χ sDescription: Surname - The surname of some person,
Χ sSource-url: http://xmlns.com/foaf/spec/20140114.html#term_surname
Χ sStatus: archaic
Χ sDomain: having this property implies being a Person
Χ rdfs:isDefinedBy: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/

Χ sDescriptionLong: A number of naming constructs are under development to provide naming substructure; draft properties include firstName, givenName, and surname. These are not currently stable or consistent; see the issue tracker for design discussions, status and ongoing work on rationalising the FOAF naming machinery,
There is also a simple name property.
* McsEngl.foaf/surname,
* McsEngl.surname@foaf,

foaf:theme-property::
Χ sDescription: theme - A theme,
Χ sSource-url: http://xmlns.com/foaf/spec/20140114.html#term_theme
Χ sStatus: archaic
Χ sDomain: having this property implies being a Thing
Χ sRange: every value of this property is a Thing
Χ rdfs:isDefinedBy: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/

Χ sDescriptionLong:
Χ editorial: This property is considered archaic usage, and is not currently recommended for usage,
The theme property is rarely used and under-specified. The intention was to use it to characterise interest / themes associated with projects and groups. Further work is needed to meet these goals.
* McsEngl.foaf/theme,
* McsEngl.theme@foaf,

ontology.eli

description::
"The European Legislation Identifier (ELI) is a framework to make legislation metadata available online in a standardised format, so that it can be accessed, exchanged and reused across borders. For general information about ELI (governance, tools and news), and the implementation status of ELI by various stakeholders (in particular, the way ELI is implemented by the Office of Publications on Eur- Lex), please consult the ELI Register on Eur-Lex."

ontology.skos

description::
· skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#"
"SKOS is a vocabulary for publishing classification schemes such as terminologies and thesauri on the Web. SKOS is since 2009 a W3C recommendation and is widely used in the library world. The Library of Congress published its Subject Headings as a SKOS vocabulary."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/NOTE-rdf11-primer-20140624/#section-vocabulary]
===
"Simple Knowledge Organization System (SKOS) is a W3C recommendation designed for representation of thesauri, classification schemes, taxonomies, subject-heading systems, or any other type of structured controlled vocabulary. SKOS is part of the Semantic Web family of standards built upon RDF and RDFS, and its main objective is to enable easy publication and use of such vocabularies as linked data."
[{2021-01-24} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Knowledge_Organization_System]

ontology.BORO

description::
">overview of Business Objects Reference Ontology:
Business Objects Reference Ontology (BORO) is a top-level ontology designed for developing ontological or semantic models for large complex operational applications. It consists of a top-level ontology as well as a process for constructing the ontology. BORO was originally conceived in the late 1980s to address a particular need for a solid legacy re-engineering process and then evolved to address a wider need for developing enterprise systems in a 'better way'.

**Key features of BORO:**
* **Simplicity:** BORO is a simple, repeatable process for developing formal ontologies.
* **Extensionality:** BORO takes an extensional approach to ontology development, which means that it is grounded in physical reality.
* **Grounding in metaphysics:** BORO is built upon a series of clear metaphysical choices, which provides a solid metaphysical foundation.

**Benefits of using BORO:**
* **Improved communication and understanding:** BORO can improve communication and understanding between different stakeholders in an organization.
* **Reduced development costs:** BORO can reduce development costs by enabling the reuse of components.
* **Enhanced interoperability:** BORO can enhance interoperability between different systems.

**Applications of BORO:**
* **Enterprise architecture:** BORO can be used to develop enterprise architecture models.
* **Systems integration:** BORO can be used to integrate different systems.
* **Data modeling:** BORO can be used to develop data models.
* **Knowledge representation:** BORO can be used to represent knowledge.

**BORO in the context of Digital Twins:**
BORO can play a valuable role in the development of Digital Twins by providing a common ontology for representing the different aspects of a Digital Twin. This can help to ensure that the different parts of a Digital Twin are interoperable and that they can be easily understood by different stakeholders.

**Overall, BORO is a powerful and versatile tool for developing ontological or semantic models for large complex operational applications. It is a well-established and widely-used approach that has been successfully applied in a variety of domains.**
Sources
digitaltwinhub.co.uk/top-level-ontologies/business-objects-reference-ontology-r2/"
[{2023-11-19 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/33337b565dbef609?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.BORO!=Business-Objects-Reference-Ontology,
* McsEngl.knOnto.BORO,

ontology.CIDOC-CRM

description::
"The CIDOC CRM represents an 'ontology' for cultural heritage information i.e. it describes in a formal language the explicit and implicit concepts and relations relevant to the documentation of cultural heritage. The primary role of the CIDOC CRM is to serve as a basis for mediation of cultural heritage information and thereby provide the semantic 'glue' needed to transform today's disparate, localised information sources into a coherent and valuable global resource.
The CIDOC CRM is intended to promote a shared understanding of cultural heritage information by providing a common and extensible semantic framework that any cultural heritage information can be mapped to. It is intended to be a common language for domain experts and implementers to formulate requirements for information systems and to serve as a guide for good practice of conceptual modelling. In this way, it can provide the "semantic glue" needed to mediate between different sources of cultural heritage information, such as that published by museums, libraries and archives.
The CIDOC CRM is the culmination of over 10 years work by the CIDOC Documentation Standards Working Group and CIDOC CRM SIG which are working groups of CIDOC. Since 9/12/2006 it is official standard ISO 21127:2006."
[{2021-01-26} http://www.cidoc-crm.org/node/202]

name::
* McsEngl.CIDOC-CRM-ontology,
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.CIDOC-CRM,
* McsEngl.ontgCIDOC-CRM,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.CIDOC-CRM,

ontology.DBpedia

description::
"The English version of the DBpedia knowledge base describes 4.58 million things, out of which 4.22 million are classified in a consistent ontology, including 1,445,000 persons, 735,000 places (including 478,000 populated places), 411,000 creative works (including 123,000 music albums, 87,000 films and 19,000 video games), 241,000 organizations (including 58,000 companies and 49,000 educational institutions), 251,000 species and 6,000 diseases."
[{2021-01-30} https://wiki.dbpedia.org/about]

ontology.PROV-{2017}

description::
"* **2017:** The W3C publishes the PROV Ontology, which is a vocabulary for describing the provenance of data." [{2023-11-04 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/d9d14f2406f370df]
"overview of PROV-Ontology:
The PROV Ontology (PROV-O) is a Web Ontology Language (OWL) ontology that defines a conceptual data model for provenance information. It is intended to be used to represent and interchange provenance information in a variety of application domains.

PROV-O is based on the PROV Data Model (PROV-DM), which defines a minimal set of concepts to represent provenance information. PROV-O adds additional classes and properties to provide a more expressive vocabulary for provenance modeling.

PROV-O can be used to represent a variety of provenance information, including:
* Entities: the entities involved in producing a piece of data or thing, such as people, organizations, software tools, and data files.
* Activities: the activities that were performed to produce a piece of data or thing, such as generating data, transforming data, and publishing data.
* Relationships between entities and activities: how entities are related to each other and to the activities that produced them.

PROV-O is designed to be extensible, so that new classes and properties can be added to model provenance information for specific applications and domains.

PROV-O is used in a variety of applications, including:
* Scientific data management: to track the provenance of scientific data, so that scientists can understand how the data was produced and assess its reliability.
* Software engineering: to track the provenance of software artifacts, so that developers can understand how the software was produced and debug problems.
* Web publishing: to track the provenance of web pages and other web resources, so that users can understand how the content was created and assess its trustworthiness.

Here are some examples of how PROV-O can be used to represent provenance information:
* A scientist uses a software tool to generate a dataset of experimental results. PROV-O can be used to represent the relationship between the scientist, the software tool, and the dataset, as well as the activity of generating the dataset.
* A software developer writes a program that transforms one dataset into another dataset. PROV-O can be used to represent the relationship between the two datasets, the program, and the activity of transforming the data.
* A web publisher creates a web page that cites a research paper. PROV-O can be used to represent the relationship between the web page, the research paper, and the activity of citing the paper.

PROV-O is a powerful tool for representing and interchanging provenance information in a variety of application domains. It is based on open standards and is supported by a number of tools and libraries."
[{2023-11-04 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/1183569c9a4037f0]

name::
* McsEngl.PROV-ontology,
* McsEngl.Knlgbase.PROV,
* McsEngl.ontgProv,
* McsEngl.kbOnto.PROV,

manager of lagOntg

description::
· a-knowledge-language--manager for ontology-languages.

">overview of ontology editors:
Ontology editors are specialized software applications designed to assist in the creation, editing, and management of ontologies. Ontologies are formal representations of knowledge that are used in a variety of fields, including artificial intelligence, knowledge engineering, and information science. Ontology editors provide a variety of features to help users create and manage ontologies, such as:
* **Visual editing:** Ontology editors often provide a visual interface that allows users to create and edit ontologies by dragging and dropping elements onto a canvas. This can make it easier to understand and modify complex ontologies.
* **Error checking:** Ontology editors can check for errors in ontologies, such as missing or conflicting information. This can help to ensure that ontologies are well-formed and consistent.
* **Reasoning:** Some ontology editors include reasoning engines that can be used to infer new information from ontologies. This can be useful for tasks such as query answering and classification.
* **Import/export:** Ontology editors can import and export ontologies in a variety of formats, including RDF, OWL, and OBO. This makes it possible to share ontologies with others and to use them with different software applications.

There are a number of different ontology editors available, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. Some of the most popular ontology editors include:
* **Protégé:** Protégé is a free and open-source ontology editor that is widely used in the academic and research communities. It is a powerful and flexible tool that supports a wide range of features.
* **OntoStudio:** OntoStudio is a commercial ontology editor that is used by a number of large organizations. It is a user-friendly tool that is easy to learn and use.
* **TopBraid Composer:** TopBraid Composer is another commercial ontology editor that is used by a number of large organizations. It is a powerful and flexible tool that supports a wide range of features.
* **Visual OWL:** Visual OWL is a free and open-source ontology editor that is specifically designed for editing OWL ontologies. It is a lightweight and easy-to-use tool that is a good choice for beginners.
* **JENA Fuseki:** JENA Fuseki is an open-source ontology editor that is based on the JENA framework. It is a powerful and flexible tool that is a good choice for developers.

Choosing the right ontology editor for your needs will depend on a number of factors, such as your experience level, budget, and specific requirements. It is a good idea to try out a few different editors before making a decision."
[{2023-11-15 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/73bf79ced88777e9?hl=en&pli=1]

klmrOntology.WebProtégé of lagOntg

description::
× webaddress: https://webprotege.stanford.edu/

"WebProtégé is an ontology development environment for the Web that makes it easy to create, upload, modify, and share ontologies for collaborative viewing and editing.
WebProtégé fully supports the latest OWL 2 Web Ontology Language. The highly configurable user interface creates the perfect environment for beginners and experts alike. Collaboration features abound, including sharing and permissions, threaded notes and discussions, watches and email notifications. RDF/XML, Turtle, OWL/XML, OBO, and other formats available for ontology upload and download.
* W3C standards compliant
* Simple, customizable user interface
* Optimized for collaboration
* Change tracking and revision history
* Web forms for domain specific editing
* Multiple upload/download formats
* Cross compatible with Protιgι Desktop"
[{2021-01-28} https://protege.stanford.edu/products.php#web-protege]
===
"WebProtégé is a web-based ontology editor that allows users to create, edit, and manage ontologies in a collaborative environment. It is built on top of the Protégé ontology editor and provides a number of features that make it ideal for developing and maintaining large and complex ontologies.

WebProtégé includes the following features:
* A collaborative user interface that allows multiple users to edit the same ontology at the same time.
* A variety of tools for editing and managing ontologies, including a class browser, property browser, and individual browser.
* Support for a variety of ontology formats, including RDF/XML, Turtle, OWL/XML, and OBO.
* Integration with a number of other tools and resources, such as BioPortal and the NCBO Ontology Repository.

WebProtégé is used by a wide range of users, including researchers, developers, and practitioners in a variety of fields, such as biomedical informatics, artificial intelligence, and knowledge engineering.

Here are some of the benefits of using WebProtégé:
* **Collaboration:** WebProtégé allows multiple users to edit the same ontology at the same time, making it ideal for collaborative ontology development.
* **Ease of use:** WebProtégé provides a user-friendly interface that makes it easy to create, edit, and manage ontologies.
* **Expressiveness:** WebProtégé supports a wide range of ontology languages, including OWL and OBO, allowing users to create highly expressive ontologies.
* **Integration:** WebProtégé integrates with a number of other tools and resources, such as BioPortal and the NCBO Ontology Repository, making it easy to find and reuse existing ontologies.

If you are developing or maintaining an ontology, I highly recommend using WebProtégé. It is a powerful and flexible tool that can help you to create and manage ontologies more efficiently and effectively."

evoluting of lagOntg

description::
"evolution of ontology-languages:
The evolution of ontology languages reflects the growing need for structured and formal representations of knowledge in various fields, particularly in the realms of artificial intelligence, knowledge representation, and the Semantic Web. Here is an overview of the evolution of ontology languages:

1. **Early Knowledge Representation Systems:** Before the term "ontology" became widely adopted, early knowledge representation systems used logic-based formalisms, such as predicate logic, frames, and semantic networks, to represent structured knowledge. These systems laid the foundation for modern ontology languages.

2. **KIF (Knowledge Interchange Format):** In the late 1980s, the development of KIF began as an early attempt to create a standard language for expressing knowledge and ontologies in a machine-readable format.

3. **Frame-Based Systems:** Frame-based systems like KL-ONE, developed in the 1980s, provided a way to represent structured knowledge with a focus on classes and instances, influencing the development of ontology languages.

4. **RDF (Resource Description Framework):** The late 1990s saw the emergence of RDF as a standardized way to represent resources and their relationships in a simple, graph-based format. RDF formed the basis for the development of the Semantic Web.

5. **RDF Schema (RDFS):** RDFS was introduced as an extension of RDF to allow for the creation of simple ontologies with concepts, properties, and hierarchies.

6. **OWL (Web Ontology Language):** The early 2000s marked a significant milestone with the release of OWL, a family of ontology languages designed to represent knowledge on the Semantic Web. OWL introduced more expressive power, allowing for complex modeling and reasoning capabilities. It defined three profiles: OWL Lite, OWL DL, and OWL Full, each offering different levels of expressiveness and reasoning complexity.

7. **Description Logics (DLs):** OWL was built upon description logics, a family of formal logic-based languages for representing and reasoning about knowledge. Description logics provide a theoretical foundation for OWL and influenced its development.

8. **Standardization and Tooling:** The development of ontology languages was paralleled by the standardization of ontology-related technologies and the creation of tools like Protιgι, which made ontology development more accessible.

9. **Ontology Engineering Methodologies:** Various methodologies for ontology engineering, such as the Methontology methodology and NeOn methodology, have been developed to guide the creation, maintenance, and evolution of ontologies.

10. **Integration with Databases and AI:** Ontology languages are increasingly integrated into AI systems, databases, and natural language processing to enhance data integration, knowledge discovery, and semantic search.

11. **Emerging Semantic Technologies:** Ongoing research and development continue to push the boundaries of ontology languages, including efforts to merge ontologies with emerging technologies like blockchain, knowledge graphs, and AI-driven ontology generation.

The evolution of ontology languages has been driven by the need to represent and reason about complex knowledge and has significantly impacted fields such as artificial intelligence, the Semantic Web, and knowledge management. As technologies and requirements continue to evolve, ontology languages and their associated tools and methodologies will likely continue to adapt and expand."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/b772e8ef-c6be-489f-8ad4-69895bc95406]

"evolution of ontology-language:
The evolution of ontology languages can be traced back to the early days of artificial intelligence (AI) research, in the 1970s and 1980s. During this time, a number of different ontology languages were developed, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. Some of the most notable early ontology languages include:
* **KL-ONE** (1984): One of the first ontology languages to be developed, KL-ONE was based on description logic, a formal logic for representing and reasoning about concepts and their relationships.
* **LOOM** (1992): A successor to KL-ONE, LOOM was a more expressive ontology language that supported a wider range of reasoning tasks.
* **CycL** (1992): A large-scale ontology language that was developed to represent the common-sense knowledge of the world.

In the 1990s, there was a growing interest in using ontologies to develop intelligent web applications. This led to the development of a number of new ontology languages that were specifically designed for the World Wide Web. Some of the most notable ontology languages from this era include:
* **DAML** (2000): DARPA Agent Markup Language, developed by the US Department of Defense.
* **OIL** (2000): Ontology Inference Layer, developed by the European Union.

In 2001, DAML and OIL were merged to form DAML+OIL. DAML+OIL was a powerful ontology language that supported a wide range of reasoning tasks. However, it was also complex and difficult to use.

In 2004, the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) published the Web Ontology Language (OWL). OWL was a simplified version of DAML+OIL that was designed to be easier to use and more accessible to a wider range of users. OWL has since become the de facto standard ontology language for the Web.

The evolution of ontology languages has been driven by a number of factors, including the need for more expressive and powerful languages, the need for languages that are easier to use, and the need for languages that are specifically designed for the Web.

In recent years, there has been a growing interest in developing ontology languages that are more scalable and efficient. This has led to the development of a number of new ontology languages, such as SWRL (Semantic Web Rule Language) and SHACL (Shapes Constraint Language).

Ontology languages are now used in a wide range of applications, including:
* **Semantic Web:** Ontologies are used to represent the meaning of data on the Semantic Web.
* **Knowledge management:** Ontologies are used to organize and manage knowledge in knowledge bases.
* **Artificial intelligence:** Ontologies are used to develop intelligent agents that can reason about the world.
* **Data science:** Ontologies are used to integrate data from different sources and to extract new insights from data.

The evolution of ontology languages is ongoing, and new languages are being developed all the time. As ontology languages continue to evolve, they will play an increasingly important role in the development of intelligent web applications and knowledge-based systems."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/56738e883ec8db69]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-lagOntg,
* McsEngl.lagOntg'evoluting,

name::
* McsEngl.lagOntg.specific,

lagOntg.concept

description::
"overview of concept-language:
Concept-language (CL) is a simple ontology language that is easy to learn and use. It is often used for educational purposes, or for developing small ontologies.

CL ontologies are made up of two main components: concepts and relations. Concepts represent the different types of things that exist in the world, such as people, places, and events. Relations represent the relationships between concepts, such as the relationship between a parent and a child.

CL ontologies are written in a text-based format, and can be edited with a text editor. The following is a simple example of a CL ontology:
```
concept Person
concept Parent
concept Child

relation parentOf(Person, Person)
```

This ontology defines two concepts, `Person` and `Parent`, and one relation, `parentOf`. The `parentOf` relation can be used to represent the relationship between a parent and a child.

CL ontologies can be used to represent a wide range of knowledge, such as the knowledge about a family, the knowledge about a product catalog, or the knowledge about a scientific domain.

Here are some of the benefits of using CL:
* It is easy to learn and use, even for people with no prior experience with ontology languages.
* It is a lightweight language, which means that CL ontologies can be created and edited quickly and easily.
* It is flexible and expressive, which means that CL can be used to represent a wide range of knowledge.
* There are a number of tools and resources available to help people create and use CL ontologies.

However, CL also has some limitations:
* It is not as powerful as some other ontology languages, such as OWL.
* It is not as widely supported as some other ontology languages.

Overall, CL is a good choice for developing small, simple ontologies. It is also a good choice for educational purposes.

Here are some examples of how CL can be used:
* To represent the knowledge about a family, you could create a CL ontology with the following concepts: `Person`, `Parent`, `Child`, `Sibling`, and `Grandparent`. You could then use the `parentOf` relation to represent the relationships between the different concepts.
* To represent the knowledge about a product catalog, you could create a CL ontology with the following concepts: `Product`, `Category`, and `Attribute`. You could then use the `isA` relation to represent the relationship between a product and a category, and the `hasAttribute` relation to represent the relationship between a product and an attribute.
* To represent the knowledge about a scientific domain, you could create a CL ontology with the following concepts: `Gene`, `Protein`, and `Pathway`. You could then use the `interactsWith` relation to represent the interactions between the different concepts.

CL is a versatile and easy-to-use ontology language that can be used to represent a wide range of knowledge."
[{2023-10-24 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/56e1224934fd79d9]

name::
* McsEngl.concept-lagOntg,
* McsEngl.lagOntg.concept,

* RDF-(Resource Description Framework),
* SHOE,

name::

lagOntg.OWL

description::
"Ontologies are formalized vocabularies of terms, often covering a specific domain and shared by a community of users.
They specify the definitions of terms by describing their relationships with other terms in the ontology."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/TR/owl2-overview/]

name::
* McsEngl.OWL!=web-ontology-language!⇒lagOwlg,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.026-OWL!⇒lagOwlg,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.OWL!⇒lagOwlg,
* McsEngl.lagOwlg!=web-ontology-language-OWL,
* McsEngl.web-ontology-language!⇒lagOwlg,

descriptionLong::
"The Web Ontology Language (OWL) is a family of knowledge representation languages for authoring ontologies. Ontologies are a formal way to describe taxonomies and classification networks, essentially defining the structure of knowledge for various domains: the nouns representing classes of objects and the verbs representing relations between the objects.
Ontologies resemble class hierarchies in object-oriented programming but there are several critical differences. Class hierarchies are meant to represent structures used in source code that evolve fairly slowly (perhaps with monthly revisions) whereas ontologies are meant to represent information on the Internet and are expected to be evolving almost constantly. Similarly, ontologies are typically far more flexible as they are meant to represent information on the Internet coming from all sorts of heterogeneous data sources. Class hierarchies on the other hand tend to be fairly static and rely on far less diverse and more structured sources of data such as corporate databases.[1]
The OWL languages are characterized by formal semantics. They are built upon the World Wide Web Consortium's (W3C) XML standard for objects called the Resource Description Framework (RDF).[2] OWL and RDF have attracted significant academic, medical and commercial interest.
In October 2007,[3] a new W3C working group[4] was started to extend OWL with several new features as proposed in the OWL 1.1 member submission.[5] W3C announced the new version of OWL on 27 October 2009.[6] This new version, called OWL 2, soon found its way into semantic editors such as Protιgι and semantic reasoners such as Pellet,[7] RacerPro,[8] FaCT++[9][10] and HermiT.[11]
The OWL family contains many species, serializations, syntaxes and specifications with similar names. OWL and OWL2 are used to refer to the 2004 and 2009 specifications, respectively. Full species names will be used, including specification version (for example, OWL2 EL). When referring more generally, OWL Family will be used.[12][13][14]"
[{2021-01-03} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Ontology_Language]

input of lagOwlg

description::
"The W3C OWL 2 Web Ontology Language (OWL) is a Semantic Web language designed to represent rich and complex knowledge about things, groups of things, and relations between things."
[{2021-01-08} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-primer-20121211/#Introduction]
===
"An ontology is a set of precise descriptive statements about some part of the world (usually referred to as the domain of interest or the subject matter of the ontology)."
[{2021-01-08} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-primer-20121211/#What_is_OWL_2.3F]

IRI of Owlinput

description::
"Each ontology may have an ontology IRI, which is used to identify an ontology. If an ontology has an ontology IRI, the ontology may additionally have a version IRI, which is used to identify the version of the ontology. The version IRI may be, but need not be, equal to the ontology IRI. An ontology without an ontology IRI must not contain a version IRI."
[{2021-01-10} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-syntax-20121211/#Ontologies]

name::
* McsEngl.Owlinput'IRI,

version of Owlinput

description::
"Each ontology may have an ontology IRI, which is used to identify an ontology. If an ontology has an ontology IRI, the ontology may additionally have a version IRI, which is used to identify the version of the ontology. The version IRI may be, but need not be, equal to the ontology IRI. An ontology without an ontology IRI must not contain a version IRI."
[{2021-01-10} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-syntax-20121211/#Ontologies]

Owlentity.individual

description::
"All atomic constituents of statements, be they objects (John, Mary), categories (female) or relations (married) are called entities.
In OWL 2, we denote objects as individuals, categories as classes and relations as properties."

Owlproperty.object

description::
"Properties in OWL 2 are further subdivided.
Object properties relate objects to objects (like a person to their spouse), while datatype properties assign data values to objects (like an age to a person).
Annotation properties are used to encode information about (parts of) the ontology itself (like the author and creation date of an axiom) instead of the domain of interest."
[{2021-01-09} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-primer-20121211/#Modeling_Knowledge:_Basic_Notions]

name::
* McsEngl.Owlproperty.object,

vocabulary of Owlinput

description::
"Entities are the fundamental building blocks of OWL 2 ontologies, and they define the vocabulary — the named terms — of an ontology.
In logic, the set of entities is usually said to constitute the signature of an ontology.
Apart from entities, OWL 2 ontologies typically also contain literals, such as strings or integers."
[{2021-01-10} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-syntax-20121211/#Entities.2C_Literals.2C_and_Anonymous_Individuals]

name::

* McsEngl.vocabulary@lagOwlg,

literal of Owlinput

description::
"Literals represent data values such as particular strings or integers.
They are analogous to typed RDF literals [RDF Concepts] and can also be understood as individuals denoting data values."
[{2021-01-10} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-syntax-20121211/#Literals]

name::
* McsEngl.Owlliteral,
* McsEngl.Owlinput'literal!⇒Owlliteral,

axiom of Owlinput

description::
"Now, in order to formulate knowledge explicitly, it is useful to assume that it consists of elementary pieces that are often referred to as statements or propositions. Statements like “it is raining” or “every man is mortal” are typical examples for such basic propositions. Indeed, every OWL 2 ontology is essentially just a collection of such basic “pieces of knowledge.” Statements that are made in an ontology are called axioms in OWL 2, and the ontology asserts that its axioms are true. In general, OWL statements might be either true or false given a certain state of affairs. This distinguishes them from entities and expressions as described further below."
[{2021-01-09} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-primer-20121211/#Modeling_Knowledge:_Basic_Notions]

name::
* McsEngl.Owlaxiom,
* McsEngl.Owlinput'axiom!⇒Owlaxiom,
* McsEngl.axiom@lagOwlg,

annotation of Owlinput

description::
"OWL 2 applications often need ways to associate additional information with ontologies, entities, and axioms. To this end, OWL 2 provides for annotations on ontologies, axioms, and entities.
eample: One might want to associate human-readable labels with IRIs and use them when visualizing an ontology. To this end, one might use the rdfs:label annotation property to associate such labels with ontology IRIs."
[{2021-01-10} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-syntax-20121211/#Annotations]

name::
* McsEngl.Owlannotation,
* McsEngl.Owlinput'annotation!⇒Owlannotation,

open-world-assumption of Owlinput

description::
"If some fact is not present in a database, it is usually considered false (the so-called closed-world assumption) whereas in the case of an OWL 2 document it may simply be missing (but possibly true), following the open-world assumption."
[{2021-01-08} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-primer-20121211/#What_is_OWL_2.3F]

name::
* McsEngl.Owlinput'open-world-assumption,
* McsEngl.lagOwlg'open-world-assumption,
* McsEngl.open-world-assumption@lagOwlg,

descriptionLong::
"In addition, OWL makes an open world assumption. That is, descriptions of resources are not confined to a single file or scope. While class C1 may be defined originally in ontology O1, it can be extended in other ontologies. The consequences of these additional propositions about C1 are monotonic. New information cannot retract previous information. New information can be contradictory, but facts and entailments can only be added, never deleted.
The possibility of such contradictions is something the designer of an ontology needs to take into consideration. It is expected that tool support will help detect such cases.
[http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-owl-guide-20040210/]

output of lagOwlg

description::
· the-output of the-mapping.
===
"An OWL 2 ontology is an abstract notion defined in terms of the structural specification. Each ontology is associated with an ontology document, which physically contains the ontology stored in a particular way. The name "ontology document" reflects the expectation that a large number of ontologies will be stored in physical text documents written in one of the syntaxes of OWL 2. OWL 2 tools, however, are free to devise other types of ontology documents — that is, to introduce other ways of physically storing ontologies."
[{2021-01-10} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-syntax-20121211/#Ontologies]

name::
* McsEngl.Owloutput,
* McsEngl.lagOwlg'document!⇒Owloutput,
* McsEngl.lagOwlg'output!⇒Owloutput,

name::
* McsEngl.Owlontology,
* McsEngl.lagOwlg'output-system!⇒Owlontology,

Owlontology.Bibo

description::
"Bibo, the Bibliographic Ontology developed by Bruce D’Arcus and Frιdιrick Giasson in 2009, is the first OWL ontology that provides main concepts and properties for describing bibliographic entities and citations. Bibo’s properties have been used since 2011 in the BNB Linked Data Platform, which provides access to the British National Bibliography published as linked open data. The Linked Data Service of the Deutsche Nationalbibliothek also has used Bibo since 2010. Bibo includes five principal classes and 34 subclasses, 32 object properties and 20 sub-properties, 20 datatype properties (10 of which are OWL equivalent properties) and 26 sub-properties. Bibo presents a variety of entities related to the bibliographic world, organized into five principal classes: Agent, Collection, Document, Document Status, Event, and 34 subclasses. The classes Document and Collection accommodate most of the bibliographic sub-entities. Among the subclasses of Document, there are Article, Book, Image, Legal Document, Manuscript, Report, Web page, etc. Among the subclasses of Collection, there are Periodical, Series, and Web site.
Even though the developers of Bibo curated sound definitions of the classes that belong to the bibliographic field, it is worth mentioning that this ontology is not very detailed with respect to the properties required in a bibliographic environment. Although it represents the translations of bibliographic resources, the properties that concern derivative, merging, and absorbed resources, which are provided instead by BIBFRAME, are not represented in Bibo. The aforementioned properties refer to two different categories of relationships very relevant in the bibliographic field: derivative relationships, which concern different editions of the same work and works derived from a pre-existing work, and sequential relationships that include sequels of a monograph, the logical continuation of, or the transformation of another work (Tillett 1989; Green 2001; IFLA 2017, 69-78)."
[{2021-01-26} https://www.isko.org/cyclo/ontologies#6]

name::
* McsEngl.Bibo-Owlontology,
* McsEngl.Owlontology.Bibo,

name::

evoluting of lagOwlg

description::
">evolution of Web Ontology Language:
The Web Ontology Language (OWL) has undergone significant evolution since its inception, with each revision introducing new features and capabilities that have expanded its scope and applicability. Let's delve into the key milestones in the evolution of OWL:

**Early Developments:**
- **1995:** SHOE (Simple HTML Ontology Extensions) is developed at the University of Maryland, laying the groundwork for ontology representation on the web.
- **1996/1997:** Ontobroker emerges from the University of Karlsruhe, providing a knowledge representation platform for building ontologies.
- **1997-1999:** The OIL (Ontology Interchange Level) project, led by an EU consortium, aims to standardize ontology languages for knowledge sharing.

**Standardization and OWL 1:**
- **2000:** The Semantic Web Activity is initiated within the W3C, fostering the development of machine-interpretable web content.
- **2000-2001:** DAML (DARPA Agent Markup Language) and OIL merge into DAML+OIL, a joint US/EU effort to create a standardized ontology language.
- **2001:** The W3C Web Ontology Working Group is established, tasked with developing an ontology language for the Semantic Web.
- **2002:** The first working drafts of OWL are published, based on lessons learned from DAML+OIL.
- **2004:** OWL 1.0 becomes a W3C Recommendation, providing a foundation for representing rich semantics on the web.

**OWL 2 and Extensions:**
- **2007:** OWL 2 is introduced, encompassing three increasingly expressive levels: OWL 2 DL, OWL 2 QL, and OWL 2 Full.
- **2009:** OWL 2 DL becomes a W3C Recommendation, offering full logical reasoning capabilities.
- **2012:** OWL 2 QL and OWL 2 Full receive W3C Recommendations, catering to specific use cases requiring efficient reasoning or unrestricted expressiveness.
- **2014:** The OWL 2 Web Ontology Language Reference is published, providing a comprehensive specification of the language.

**OWL 2 Profiles and Ongoing Developments:**
- **2017:** OWL 2 Document Format (RDF/XML) is introduced, standardizing the serialization of OWL ontologies.
- **2019:** OWL 2 Manchester Syntax and Functional Syntax are standardized, providing alternative ways to represent OWL ontologies.
- **2020:** OWL 2 WSDL Profile is introduced, enabling the integration of OWL ontologies into Web Services Description Language (WSDL).

- **Ongoing:** The W3C OWL Working Group continues to explore extensions and refinements to the language, addressing emerging requirements in knowledge representation and reasoning.

The evolution of OWL reflects the growing need for standardized and expressive ontology languages to support the Semantic Web and enable knowledge-driven applications. As the Semantic Web continues to mature, OWL is expected to play a pivotal role in enabling machines to understand and reason about the vast amount of information available on the web."
[{2023-11-15 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/c03b4ab82bdfc63f?hl=en&pli=1]

">evolution of Web Ontology Language:
The Web Ontology Language (OWL) is a family of knowledge representation languages for authoring ontologies, and it has played a crucial role in the development of the Semantic Web. The evolution of OWL can be traced through its different versions:

1. **OWL 1.0 (2004):** The first version of OWL, known as OWL Lite, OWL DL (Description Logic), and OWL Full, was published by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) in 2004. It provided a standardized way to represent and share ontologies on the web, supporting different levels of expressivity.

2. **OWL 1.1 (2007):** OWL 1.1 was designed to address some limitations and issues identified in OWL 1.0. It introduced additional features and improvements while maintaining compatibility with OWL 1.0.

3. **OWL 2 (2009):** The major evolution in the OWL language came with the release of OWL 2 in 2009. OWL 2 is a modular language that includes profiles, each catering to different use cases. The profiles include OWL 2 EL, OWL 2 QL, OWL 2 RL, OWL 2 DL, and OWL 2 Full. This modular approach allows users to choose the appropriate level of expressivity based on their specific needs.
- **OWL 2 EL:** Designed for scalable reasoning.
- **OWL 2 QL:** Suitable for querying large amounts of data.
- **OWL 2 RL:** Focused on rule-based reasoning.
- **OWL 2 DL:** Provides the maximum expressivity while maintaining decidability.
- **OWL 2 Full:** Retains compatibility with OWL Full from OWL 1.0.

4. **OWL 2.0 (2012):** Although there isn't a distinct version known as OWL 2.0, the improvements and changes made in OWL 2 over its predecessors are sometimes collectively referred to as "OWL 2.0."

5. **Continued Updates:** The development of OWL has continued with updates to its specifications, tools, and implementations. The community actively contributes to discussions and improvements in the field of ontology engineering.

Throughout its evolution, OWL has become a standard in the Semantic Web community, providing a means to represent and reason about knowledge in a machine-readable way. The ongoing work in this field aims to address practical issues, enhance usability, and accommodate evolving requirements in various domains."
[{2023-11-15 retrieved} https://chat.openai.com/c/eb82a0bc-071d-4172-99db-e43bc4a740b1]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-lagOwlg,
* McsEngl.lagOwlg'evoluting,

lagOwlg.OWL2-{2009}

description::
"Relationship to OWL 1
OWL 2 has a very similar overall structure to OWL 1. Looking at Figure 1, almost all the building blocks of OWL 2 were present in OWL 1, albeit possibly under different names.
The central role of RDF/XML, the role of other syntaxes, and the relationships between the Direct and RDF-Based semantics (i.e., the correspondence theorem) have not changed. More importantly, backwards compatibility with OWL 1 is, to all intents and purposes, complete: all OWL 1 Ontologies remain valid OWL 2 Ontologies, with identical inferences in all practical cases (see Section 4.2 of OWL 2 New Features and Rationale [OWL 2 New Features and Rationale]).
OWL 2 adds new functionality with respect to OWL 1. Some of the new features are syntactic sugar (e.g., disjoint union of classes) while others offer new expressivity, including:
* keys;
* property chains;
* richer datatypes, data ranges;
* qualified cardinality restrictions;
* asymmetric, reflexive, and disjoint properties; and
* enhanced annotation capabilities
OWL 2 also defines three new profiles [OWL 2 Profiles] and a new syntax [OWL 2 Manchester Syntax]. In addition, some of the restrictions applicable to OWL DL have been relaxed; as a result, the set of RDF Graphs that can be handled by Description Logics reasoners is slightly larger in OWL 2.
All of the above is documented in detail in the OWL 2 New Features and Rationale document [OWL 2 New Features and Rationale]. The OWL 2 Quick Reference Guide [OWL 2 Quick Guide] also provides an overview of the features of OWL 2, clearly indicating those that are new."
[{2021-01-30} https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/REC-owl2-overview-20121211/#Relationship_to_OWL_1]

name::
* McsEngl.OWL2!⇒lagOwl2,
* McsEngl.lagOntl.OWL2!⇒lagOwl2,
* McsEngl.lagOwl2,

lagOntg.OBO

description::
"overview of OBO ontology-language:
**OBO Ontology Language** (OBO) is a text-based ontology language that is based on the Web Ontology Language (OWL). It was developed by the Open Biological and Biomedical Ontologies (OBO) Foundry, a community effort to create ontologies for use across biological and medical domains.

OBO is a relatively simple language that is easy to learn and use. It is also highly expressive, allowing users to create ontologies that are both rich and complex.

OBO ontologies are typically stored in OBO files, which are text files that use a specific syntax to define classes, properties, and individuals. OBO files can be easily processed by software tools, such as OBOEdit and Protégé.

OBO is a widely used ontology language in the biological and medical communities. It is used to create ontologies for a wide range of topics, such as genes, proteins, diseases, and drugs. OBO ontologies are used in a variety of applications, such as data integration, knowledge discovery, and machine learning.

Here is an example of a simple OBO ontology:
```
id: GO:0003674
name: molecular_function
def: The biochemical activity of a molecular entity.
is_a: GO:0005488
```

This ontology defines a class called `GO:0003674 molecular_function`. The `is_a` property indicates that this class is a subclass of the `GO:0005488 biological_process` class.

OBO ontologies can be linked together to create more complex ontologies. For example, the following OBO ontology links the `GO:0003674 molecular_function` class to the `KEGG:R01100 glycolysis/gluconeogenesis` pathway:
```
id: KEGG:R01100
name: glycolysis/gluconeogenesis
def: A metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate and vice versa.
is_a: KEGG:pathway
part_of: KEGG:metabolism
involves: GO:0003674 molecular_function
```

This ontology states that the `KEGG:R01100 glycolysis/gluconeogenesis` pathway involves the `GO:0003674 molecular_function` class. This means that the genes and proteins that are involved in the glycolysis/gluconeogenesis pathway have molecular functions.

OBO is a powerful and flexible ontology language that is widely used in the biological and medical communities. It is a good choice for creating ontologies for a wide range of topics, such as genes, proteins, diseases, and drugs."
[{2023-11-04 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/92897ea538348c4f]

name::
* McsEngl.OBO--ontology-language,
* McsEngl.lagOntg.OBO,

lagOntg.SWRL (link)

lagOntg.TTL-(turtle-format) (link)

lagOntg.SHOE

description::
">evolution of SHOE ontology language:
SHOE (Simple HTML Ontology Extensions) was an early ontology language that used HTML tags to define classes, properties, and instances. It was developed by the University of Maryland in the early 1990s. SHOE was a simple and easy-to-use language, but it was not as expressive as other ontology languages that were developed later. As a result, SHOE was never widely adopted.

SHOE was succeeded by OIL (Ontology Interchange Language), which was developed by the DARPA Agent Markup Language (DAML) program in the late 1990s. OIL was a more expressive language than SHOE, and it was designed to be interoperable with other ontology languages. OIL was never officially standardized, but it was a major influence on the development of OWL (Web Ontology Language), which is the current standard ontology language.

OWL is a powerful and expressive language that is used to define ontologies for a wide variety of applications. OWL is based on RDF (Resource Description Framework), which is a data model for representing information about resources. OWL ontologies are used to define the relationships between different types of resources, and they can be used to infer new information from existing information.

The evolution of ontology languages from SHOE to OWL has been driven by the need for more expressive and interoperable languages. SHOE was a simple language that was easy to use, but it was not as expressive as OIL or OWL. OIL was a more expressive language than SHOE, but it was not as interoperable. OWL is a powerful and expressive language that is both interoperable and easy to use.

Here is a table that summarizes the evolution of SHOE ontology language:
| Language | Developer | Year | Description |
| SHOE | University of Maryland | 1990s | Simple ontology language that used HTML tags to define classes, properties, and instances. |
| OIL | DARPA Agent Markup Language (DAML) program | Late 1990s | More expressive ontology language than SHOE, designed to be interoperable with other ontology languages. |
| OWL | World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) | 2004 | Powerful and expressive ontology language based on RDF, used to define ontologies for a wide variety of applications. |"
[{2023-11-17 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/b44cef8e3fa01ded?hl=en&pli=1]

name::
* McsEngl.SHOE!=Simple-HTML-Ontology-Extensions,
* McsEngl.Simple-HTML-Ontology-Extensions,
* McsEngl.lagOntg.SHOE,

addressWpg::
* https://www.cs.umd.edu/projects/plus/SHOE/html-pages.html,

lagKnlg.rule

description::
· rule-language is a-propositional-language that uses if-then-propositions.

name::
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.011-rule!⇒lagRule,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.rule!⇒lagRule,
* McsEngl.lagPpsl.rule!⇒lagRule,
* McsEngl.lagRule,
* McsEngl.rule-language!⇒lagRule,

descriptionLong::
"Rules are a simple way of encoding knowledge, and are a drastic simplification of first order logic, for which it is relatively easy to implement inference engines that can process the conditions and draw the right conclusions. A rule system is an implementation of a particular syntax and semantics of rules, which may extend the simple notion described above to include existential quantification, disjunction, logical conjunction, negation, functions, non monotonicity, and many other features. Rule systems have been implemented and studied since the mid-1970s and saw significant uptake in the 1980s during the height of so-called Expert Systems."
[{2021-01-30} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_Interchange_Format]

manager (link) of lagRule

lagRule.SPECIFIC

description::
* RIF,
* RuleML,
* SWRL,
===
"Rule-based languages instantiate rules when activated by conditions in a set of data. Of all possible activations, some set is selected and the statements belonging to those rules execute. Rule-based languages include:[citation needed]
* awk,
* CLIPS,
* Constraint Handling Rules,
* Drools,
* GOAL agent programming language,
* Jess,
* OPS5,
* Prolog,
* ToonTalk – robots are rules,
* Mathematica,
* XSLT[citation needed],
* Wolfram Language",
[{2021-02-01} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_programming_languages_by_type#Rule-based_languages]

name::
* McsEngl.lagRule.specific,

lagRule.RuleML

description::
"Rules have many uses, coming in a multitude of forms. RuleML is a unifying system of families of languages for Web rules over Web documents and data. RuleML is specified syntactically through schema languages (normatively, in Relax NG), originally developed for XML and transferable to other formats such as JSON. Since Version 1.02, rather than assuming predefined default semantics, RuleML allows partially constrained semantic profiles and fully-specified semantics. PSOA RuleML employs model-theoretic semantics and transformational realizations, bridges between (deductive) graph and relational databases and other data paradigms, formalizes Cypher-like labeled property graphs, and is illustrated via (blockchain, ...) examples and (air traffic control, ...) use cases."
[{2021-01-30} http://wiki.ruleml.org/index.php/Introducing_RuleML]

name::
* McsEngl.RuleML!⇒lagRlml,
* McsEngl.lagRlml,
* McsEngl.lagRule.RuleML!⇒lagRlml,

descriptionLong::
"RuleML is a global initiative, led by a non-profit organization RuleML Inc., that is devoted to advancing research and industry standards design activities in the technical area of rules that are semantic and highly inter-operable. The standards design takes the form primarily of a markup language, also known as RuleML. The research activities include an annual research conference, the RuleML Symposium, also known as RuleML for short. Founded in fall 2000 by Harold Boley, Benjamin Grosof, and Said Tabet, RuleML was originally devoted purely to standards design, but then quickly branched out into the related activities of coordinating research and organizing an annual research conference starting in 2002. The M in RuleML is sometimes interpreted as standing for Markup and Modeling. The markup language was developed to express both forward (bottom-up) and backward (top-down) rules in XML for deduction, rewriting, and further inferential-transformational tasks. It is defined by the Rule Markup Initiative, an open network of individuals and groups from both industry and academia[1] that was formed to develop a canonical Web language for rules using XML markup and transformations from and to other rule standards/systems."
[{2021-01-30} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RuleML]

lagRule.RIF

description::
"The Rule Interchange Format (RIF) is a W3C Recommendation. RIF is part of the infrastructure for the semantic web, along with (principally) SPARQL, RDF and OWL. Although originally envisioned by many as a "rules layer" for the semantic web, in reality the design of RIF is based on the observation that there are many "rules languages" in existence, and what is needed is to exchange rules between them.[1]
RIF includes three dialects, a Core dialect which is extended into a Basic Logic Dialect (BLD) and Production Rule Dialect (PRD).[2]"
[{2021-01-05} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_Interchange_Format]

name::
* McsEngl.RIF!=rule-interchange-format,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.027-RIF!⇒lagRift,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.RIF!⇒lagRift,
* McsEngl.lagRift,
* McsEngl.lagRule.RIF!⇒lagRift,
* McsEngl.rule-interchange-format!⇒lagRift,

relation-to-RuleML of lagRift

description::
"3.4 What is the relationship between RuleML and RIF?
RuleML has provided input for RIF on several levels, including the use of 'striped' XML as well as the structuring of rule classes into a family of sublanguages with, e.g., Datalog RuleML partially mappable to the RIF Core Dialect, Derivation RuleML to the RIF Basic Logic Dialect, and the production-rule sublanguage of Reaction RuleML to the RIF Production Rule Dialect. Conversely, RuleML adopted some features that were developed as part of the RIF Working Group such as role tags <if> ... <then> instead of <body> ... <head>. Shared RIF RuleML implementations and use cases are projected to lead to further convergence."
[{2021-01-30} https://www.w3.org/2005/rules/wiki/RIF_FAQ]

name::
* McsEngl.lagRift'relation-to-RullML,

info-resource of lagRift

description::
* https://www.w3.org/TR/rif-overview/,

name::
* McsEngl.lagRift'Infrsc,

lagRule.SWRL

description::
"The Semantic Web Rule Language (SWRL) is a proposed language for the Semantic Web that can be used to express rules as well as logic, combining OWL DL or OWL Lite with a subset of the Rule Markup Language (itself a subset of Datalog).[1]
The specification was submitted in May 2004 to the W3C by the National Research Council of Canada, Network Inference (since acquired by webMethods), and Stanford University in association with the Joint US/EU ad hoc Agent Markup Language Committee. The specification was based on an earlier proposal for an OWL rules language.[2][3]
SWRL has the full power of OWL DL, but at the price of decidability and practical implementations.[4] However, decidability can be regained by restricting the form of admissible rules, typically by imposing a suitable safety condition.[5]
Rules are of the form of an implication between an antecedent (body) and consequent (head). The intended meaning can be read as: whenever the conditions specified in the antecedent hold, then the conditions specified in the consequent must also hold."
[{2021-01-28} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web_Rule_Language]

name::
* McsEngl.SWRL!=semantic-web-rule-language,
* McsEngl.lagOntg.Swrl!⇒lagSwrl,
* McsEngl.lagSwrl,
* McsEngl.semantic-web-rule-language!⇒lagSwrl,

lagKnlg.semantic-web

description::
· semantic-web-language is a-language we use to make the-web readable by machines.
· from web-of-documents-(HTML) to web-of-data-(RDF) to web-of-concepts-(McsHitp).

name::
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.012-semantic-web!⇒lagSweb,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.semantic-web!⇒lagSweb,
* McsEngl.lagSweb,
* McsEngl.semantic-web-language!⇒lagSweb,

descriptionLong::
"In addition to the classic “Web of documents” W3C is helping to build a technology stack to support a “Web of data,” the sort of data you find in databases. The ultimate goal of the Web of data is to enable computers to do more useful work and to develop systems that can support trusted interactions over the network. The term “Semantic Web” refers to W3C’s vision of the Web of linked data. Semantic Web technologies enable people to create data stores on the Web, build vocabularies, and write rules for handling data. Linked data are empowered by technologies such as RDF, SPARQL, OWL, and SKOS."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/]
===
"In the original concept of the Semantic Web, software agents would have processed contents, found information from different sources, reasoned about data, and produced output."
[{2021-01-26} https://www.isko.org/cyclo/ontologies]

linked-data of lagSweb

description::
"The Semantic Web is a Web of Data — of dates and titles and part numbers and chemical properties and any other data one might conceive of. The collection of Semantic Web technologies (RDF, OWL, SKOS, SPARQL, etc.) provides an environment where application can query that data, draw inferences using vocabularies, etc.
However, to make the Web of Data a reality, it is important to have the huge amount of data on the Web available in a standard format, reachable and manageable by Semantic Web tools. Furthermore, not only does the Semantic Web need access to data, but relationships among data should be made available, too, to create a Web of Data (as opposed to a sheer collection of datasets). This collection of interrelated datasets on the Web can also be referred to as Linked Data.
To achieve and create Linked Data, technologies should be available for a common format (RDF), to make either conversion or on-the-fly access to existing databases (relational, XML, HTML, etc). It is also important to be able to setup query endpoints to access that data more conveniently. W3C provides a palette of technologies (RDF, GRDDL, POWDER, RDFa, the upcoming R2RML, RIF, SPARQL) to get access to the data."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/data.html]

name::
* McsEngl.lagLddt,
* McsEngl.lagLddt!=linked-data-language,
* McsEngl.lagSweb'linked-data!⇒lagLddt,
* McsEngl.linked-data-of-lagSweb!⇒lagLddt,

descriptionLong::
"The term Linked Data refers to a set of best practices for publishing structured data on the Web. These principles have been coined by Tim Berners-Lee in the design issue note Linked Data. The principles are:
* Use URIs as names for things
* Use HTTP URIs so that people can look up those names.
* When someone looks up a URI, provide useful information.
* Include links to other URIs. so that they can discover more things.
The idea behind these principles is on the one hand side, to use standards for the representation and the access to data on the Web. On the other hand, the principles propagate to set hyperlinks between data from different sources. These hyperlinks connect all Linked Data into a single global data graph, similar as the hyperlinks on the classic Web connect all HTML documents into a single global information space. Thus, LinkedData is to spreadsheets and databases what the Web of hypertext documents is to word processor files. The Linked Open Data cloud diagramms give an overview of the linked data sets that are available on the Web."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/wiki/LinkedData]

info-resource of lagLddt

description::
* https://json-ld.org/,
* https://github.com/digitalbazaar/jsonld.js,

name::
* McsEngl.lagLddt'Infrsc,

ontology of lagSweb

description::
"On the Semantic Web, vocabularies define the concepts and relationships (also referred to as “terms”) used to describe and represent an area of concern. Vocabularies are used to classify the terms that can be used in a particular application, characterize possible relationships, and define possible constraints on using those terms. In practice, vocabularies can be very complex (with several thousands of terms) or very simple (describing one or two concepts only).
There is no clear division between what is referred to as “vocabularies” and “ontologies”. The trend is to use the word “ontology” for more complex, and possibly quite formal collection of terms, whereas “vocabulary” is used when such strict formalism is not necessarily used or only in a very loose sense. Vocabularies are the basic building blocks for inference techniques on the Semantic Web."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/ontology]

name::
* McsEngl.lagSweb'ontology,
* McsEngl.lagSweb'vocabulary,
* McsEngl.ontology@lagSweb,
* McsEngl.vocabulary@lagSweb,

evaluation of lagSweb

description::
"The name of the OWL language itself provides a good example of the value of a Semantic Web. If one were to search for "OWL" using the Internet today most of the pages retrieved would be on the bird Owl rather than the standard OWL. With a Semantic Web it would be possible to specify the concept "Web Ontology Language" and the user would not need to worry about the various possible acronyms or synonyms as part of the search. Likewise, the user would not need to worry about homonyms crowding the search results with irrelevant data such as information about birds of prey as in this simple example."
[{2021-02-08} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frame_(artificial_intelligence)#Implementations]

name::
* McsEngl.lagSweb'evaluation,

query of lagSweb

description::
"“Query” in the Semantic Web context means technologies and protocols that can programmatically retrieve information from the Web of Data.
What is Query Used For?
The Semantic Web is a Web of data — of dates and titles and part numbers and chemical properties and any other data one might conceive of. RDF provides the foundation for publishing and linking your data. Various technologies allow you to embed data in documents (RDFa, GRDDL) or expose what you have in SQL databases, or make it available as RDF files.
However, just as relational databases or XML need specific query languages (SQL and XQuery, respectively), the Web of Data, typically represented using RDF as a data format, needs its own, RDF-specific query language and facilities. This is provided by the SPARQLquery language and the accompanying protocols. SPARQL makes it possible to send queries and receive results, e.g., through HTTP or SOAP.
Technically, SPARQL queries are based on (triple) patterns. RDF can be seen as a set of relationships among resources (i.e., RDF triples); SPARQL queries provide one or more patterns against such relationships. These triple patterns are similar to RDF triples, except that one or more of the constituent resource references are variables. A SPARQL engine would returns the resources for all triples that match these patterns.
Using SPARQL consumers of the Web of Data can extract possibly complex information (i.e., existing resource references and their relationships) which are returned, for example, in a table format. This table can be incorporated into another Web page; using this approach SPARQL provides a powerful tool to build, for example, complex mash-up sites or search engines that include data stemming from the Semantic Web."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/query]

name::
* McsEngl.lagSweb'query,

inference of lagSweb

description::
"Broadly speaking, inference on the Semantic Web can be characterized by discovering new relationships. On the Semantic Web, data is modeled as a set of (named) relationships between resources. “Inference” means that automatic procedures can generate new relationships based on the data and based on some additional information in the form of a vocabulary, e.g., a set of rules. Whether the new relationships are explicitly added to the set of data, or are returned at query time, is an implementation issue.
On the Semantic Web, the source of such extra information can be defined via vocabularies or rule sets. Both of these approaches draw upon knowledge representation techniques. In general, ontologies concentrate on classification methods, putting an emphasis on defining 'classes', 'subclasses', on how individual resources can be associated to such classes, and characterizing the relationships among classes and their instances. Rules, on the other hand, concentrate on defining a general mechanism on discovering and generating new relationships based on existing ones, much like logic programs, like Prolog, do. In the family of Semantic Web related W3C Recommendations RDFS, OWL, or SKOS are the tools of choice to define ontologies, whereas RIF has been developed to cover rule based approaches."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/inference.html]

name::
* McsEngl.lagSweb'inference,

evoluting of lagSweb

description::
"evolution of semantic-web:
The evolution of the Semantic Web can be divided into three main phases:

**Phase 1: The early years (1994-2004)**
In this phase, the foundations of the Semantic Web were laid. Tim Berners-Lee and other researchers developed the core technologies of the Semantic Web, such as the Resource Description Framework (RDF), the Web Ontology Language (OWL), and the SPARQL query language.

**Phase 2: Standardization and deployment (2004-2013)**
In this phase, the Semantic Web technologies were standardized by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) and began to be deployed in real-world applications. One of the most notable deployments was the Linked Data initiative, which aims to publish all public data on the Web in a linked and machine-readable format.

**Phase 3: Emerging applications and growth (2013-present)**
In this phase, the Semantic Web is increasingly being used to develop new and innovative applications. For example, the Semantic Web is being used to power intelligent search engines, personalized recommendation systems, and automated decision-making systems.

Here are some specific examples of the evolution of the Semantic Web:
* **2001:** Tim Berners-Lee, James Hendler, and Ora Lassila publish the article "The Semantic Web" in Scientific American, which popularizes the concept of the Semantic Web.
* **2004:** The W3C publishes the RDF and OWL standards.
* **2006:** The W3C publishes the SPARQL query language standard.
* **2007:** The Linked Data initiative is launched.
* **2011:** The W3C publishes the Schema.org vocabulary, which is a set of microdata tags that can be used to mark up the meaning of content on web pages.
* **2013:** The W3C publishes the SHACL Shapes Constraint Language, which is a language for constraining the structure and meaning of RDF data.
* **2014:** The W3C publishes the JSON-LD format, which is a way to encode RDF data in JSON.
* **2017:** The W3C publishes the PROV Ontology, which is a vocabulary for describing the provenance of data.
* **2020:** The W3C publishes the Solid project, which is a platform for personal data management using the Semantic Web.

The Semantic Web is still under development, but it is already being used to power a wide range of applications. As the Semantic Web continues to evolve, it is likely to play an increasingly important role in our lives.

Here are some examples of how the Semantic Web is being used today:
* **Search engines:** The Semantic Web is being used to develop more intelligent search engines that can understand the meaning of queries and return more relevant results.
* **Recommendation systems:** The Semantic Web is being used to develop personalized recommendation systems that can recommend products, services, and content to users based on their interests.
* **Automated decision-making systems:** The Semantic Web is being used to develop automated decision-making systems that can make decisions based on complex data sets.
* **Internet of Things (IoT):** The Semantic Web is being used to develop IoT applications that can collect, process, and analyze data from sensors and devices in a more intelligent way.
* **Life sciences:** The Semantic Web is being used to develop applications for life sciences research, such as drug discovery and clinical trials.
* **Government:** The Semantic Web is being used to develop government applications, such as e-government services and fraud detection.

The Semantic Web has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with the Web. By making data more machine-readable and understandable, the Semantic Web can enable new and innovative applications that were not possible before."
[{2023-11-04 retrieved} https://bard.google.com/chat/d9d14f2406f370df]

name::
* McsEngl.evoluting-of-lagSweb,
* McsEngl.lagSweb'evoluting,

lagSweb.RDF-{2004}

description::
"RDF is graph-based because it represents data as a collection of triples, which can be naturally seen as a graph structure. A triple consists of a subject, a predicate, and an object, which correspond to a node, an edge, and another node in a graph. Each node and edge can be identified by a URI, which makes RDF data globally unique and interoperable. RDF graphs can express complex relationships and semantics among resources, and can be easily merged and queried using standard languages and tools. For more information, you can refer to the following sources: Resource Description Framework - Wikipedia, Data Modeling with RDF(S) — GraphDB 10.0.0 documentation - Ontotext, and RDF 1.2 Concepts and Abstract Syntax - World Wide Web Consortium (W3C)."
[{2023-11-18 retrieved} https://www.bing.com/search?q=Bing+AI&showconv=1&FORM=hpcodx]
"The Resource Description Framework (RDF) is a family of World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) specifications[1] originally designed as a metadata data model. It has come to be used as a general method for conceptual description or modeling of information that is implemented in web resources, using a variety of syntax notations and data serialization formats. It is also used in knowledge management applications.
RDF was adopted as a W3C recommendation in 1999. The RDF 1.0 specification was published in 2004, the RDF 1.1 specification in 2014."
[{2021-01-03} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resource_Description_Framework]

name::
* McsEngl.RDF!=resource-description-framework!⇒lagRdfw,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.014-RDF!⇒lagRdfw,
* McsEngl.lagKnlg.RDF!⇒lagRdfw,
* McsEngl.lagRdf!⇒lagRdfw,
* McsEngl.lagRdfw!=Resource-Description-FrameWork, {2021-01-05},
* McsEngl.resource-description-framework!⇒lagRdfw,

input of lagRdfw

description::
"The Resource Description Framework (RDF) is a framework for expressing information about resources. Resources can be anything, including documents, people, physical objects, and abstract concepts.
RDF is intended for situations in which information on the Web needs to be processed by applications, rather than being only displayed to people. RDF provides a common framework for expressing this information so it can be exchanged between applications without loss of meaning. Since it is a common framework, application designers can leverage the availability of common RDF parsers and processing tools. The ability to exchange information between different applications means that the information may be made available to applications other than those for which it was originally created."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/NOTE-rdf11-primer-20140624/]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdfinput,
* McsEngl.lagRdfw'input!⇒Rdfinput,

info-resource of Rdfinput

description::
"Resources can be anything, including documents, people, physical objects, and abstract concepts."
[{2021-01-03} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/NOTE-rdf11-primer-20140624/]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdfinput'resource,
* McsEngl.Rdfiresource,
* McsEngl.lagRdfw'resource!⇒Rdfiresource,

Rdfiresource.class

description::
· a-generic Rdfiresource is-called Rdficlass.
===
"Resources may be divided into groups called classes.
The members of a class are known as instances of the class.
Classes are themselves resources.
They are often identified by IRIs and may be described using RDF properties.
The rdf:type property may be used to state that a resource is an instance of a class."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass,
* McsEngl.Rdfinput'class!⇒Rdficlass,
* McsEngl.Rdfiresource.class!⇒Rdficlass,
* McsEngl.class@lagRdfw,
* McsEngl.lagRdfw'class!⇒Rdficlass,

Rdficlass.instance

description::
· a-specific Rdficlass is-called Rdfiinstance.
===
The members of a class are known as instances of the class.
... The rdf:type property may be used to state that a resource is an instance of a class."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.instance!⇒Rdfiinstance,
* McsEngl.Rdfiinstance,

Rdficlass.extension

description::
· the-set of all Rdfiinstances of an-Rdficlass.

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.extension!⇒Rdficlass-extension,
* McsEngl.Rdficlass-extension,

descriptionLong::
"RDF distinguishes between a class and the set of its instances. Associated with each class is a set, called the class extension of the class, which is the set of the instances of the class. Two classes may have the same set of instances but be different classes. For example, the tax office may define the class of people living at the same address as the editor of this document. The Post Office may define the class of people whose address has the same zip code as the address of the author. It is possible for these classes to have exactly the same instances, yet to have different properties. Only one of the classes has the property that it was defined by the tax office, and only the other has the property that it was defined by the Post Office.
A class may be a member of its own class extension and may be an instance of itself."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

Rdficlass.subclass

description::
· a-specific but not individual of an-Rdficlass.
===
"If a class C is a subclass of a class C', then all instances of C will also be instances of C'. The rdfs:subClassOf property may be used to state that one class is a subclass of another. The term super-class is used as the inverse of subclass. If a class C' is a super-class of a class C, then all instances of C are also instances of C'."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.sublass!⇒Rdfisubclass,
* McsEngl.Rdfisubclass,

Rdficlass.rdfs:Resource

description::
"All things described by RDF are called resources, and are instances of the class rdfs:Resource. This is the class of everything. All other classes are subclasses of this class. rdfs:Resource is an instance of rdfs:Class."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.rdfs:Resource,
* McsEngl.rdfs:Resource,

Rdficlass.rdfs:Class

description::
"This is the class of resources that are RDF classes. rdfs:Class is an instance of rdfs:Class."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.rdfs:Class,
* McsEngl.rdfs:Class,

Rdficlass.rdfs:Literal

description::
"The class rdfs:Literal is the class of literal values such as strings and integers. Property values such as textual strings are examples of RDF literals.
rdfs:Literal is an instance of rdfs:Class. rdfs:Literal is a subclass of rdfs:Resource."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.rdfs:Literal,
* McsEngl.rdfs:Literal,

Rdficlass.rdfs:Datatype

description::
"rdfs:Datatype is the class of datatypes. All instances of rdfs:Datatype correspond to the RDF model of a datatype described in the RDF Concepts specification [RDF11-CONCEPTS]. rdfs:Datatype is both an instance of and a subclass of rdfs:Class. Each instance of rdfs:Datatype is a subclass of rdfs:Literal."
[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/#ch_classes]

name::
* McsEngl.Rdficlass.rdfs:Datatype,
* McsEngl.rdfs:Datatype,

[{2021-01-05} https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-rdf-schema-20140225/]
